# Service Vision and Overview — civicDebateBoard

## Executive Summary
civicDebateBoard is a mission-driven discussion platform purpose-built for high-quality civic discourse. It combines open participation with verifiable expertise, structured fact-checking, and transparent, policy-led moderation. Members of the public can raise civic questions and debate policy topics; identity- or expertise-verified contributors add qualified analysis; fact checkers annotate claims with sources; moderators enforce policy with documented rationales; and administrators govern platform-wide policies and safeguards.

The platform addresses three persistent gaps in online civic discussion: (1) low signal-to-noise that impedes constructive debate, (2) weak pathways for in-thread evidence and expertise, and (3) opaque or inconsistent moderation that undermines trust. By introducing role-based trust layers, claim-level fact-check annotations, explicit enforcement rationales, and measurable service-level expectations, civicDebateBoard aims to become a trusted venue for citizens, journalists, researchers, and policymakers to engage responsibly and learn from each other.

Context and complementary materials are available in the [Market Problem and Value Proposition](./02-market-problem-and-value-proposition.md), the [Functional Requirements Specification](./06-functional-requirements.md), and the [Business Model and Analytics Strategy](./10-business-model-and-analytics.md). A navigable index is provided in the [Documentation Index and Reading Guide](./00-toc.md).

## Objectives and Success Criteria
Strategic objectives translate into measurable outcomes. Requirements below are expressed with EARS syntax where applicable for clarity and testability.

### Strategic Objectives
- Establish a trusted environment for evidence-centered civic debate that welcomes diverse participation while elevating verifiable information.
- Provide clear, consistent, and transparent moderation and fact-check processes, including rationales and appeal mechanisms.
- Achieve sustainable operations through ethical monetization aligned with civic mission and safety guardrails.

### Key Results and Targets (12–18 months)
- Community Health and Quality
  - At least 70% of active discussions contain a sourced claim or a fact-check annotation within 24 hours of first reply.
  - Median moderation first-action times: ≤ 30 minutes for P1 (safety) during active hours; ≤ 4 hours for standard P2/P3.
  - Correction adoption rate ≥ 60% for content found materially inaccurate by accepted fact checks.
- Engagement and Reach
  - Monthly Active Users (MAU) ≥ 100,000; 90-day retention for new members ≥ 35%.
  - Verified expert participation in ≥ 20% of high-visibility threads (top decile by engagement).
  - Average time-to-first-meaningful-response on public-interest threads ≤ 10 minutes during peak hours.
- Trust and Transparency
  - ≥ 95% of enforcement actions provide machine-readable and human-readable rationales visible to impacted users.
  - ≥ 95% of appeals include written outcomes with policy references and are delivered within published SLAs.

### EARS-Formatted Success Requirements
- THE platform SHALL support roles "member", "verifiedMember", "factChecker", "moderator", and "admin" as the basis for participation and accountability.
- WHEN a user submits a P1 (safety) report, THE platform SHALL place the item in the moderation queue within 1 minute and SHALL present a receipt with a reference ID to the reporter.
- WHEN a fact-check annotation with at least one citation is submitted by a factChecker, THE platform SHALL attach it to the referenced claim and SHALL present the annotation status as "proposed", "accepted", or "contested" to readers.
- IF content is sanctioned with a warning, mute, or suspension, THEN THE platform SHALL notify the content owner with the policy basis, duration, and appeal options within 1 minute of action.
- WHERE a thread is labeled as public-interest or time-sensitive (e.g., election-related), THE platform SHALL elevate review priority and SHALL target first-action within 15 minutes during active periods.
- THE platform SHALL present timestamps, quotas, and durations in the user’s locale and timezone for clarity of notices and sanctions.

## Target Users and Use Cases
Roles define how users participate and are held accountable in business terms.

- Member (member)
  - Authenticated participant who can create and manage own posts and comments; react and vote; follow topics; bookmark; report content; and manage account settings under rate limits and policies.
  - Primary outcomes: raise civic questions; contribute experiences; signal interest via voting; report misconduct with reasoned categories.

- Verified Member (verifiedMember)
  - Identity- or expertise-verified participant with elevated trust and accountability; can create expert-tagged posts and host structured Q&A sessions.
  - Primary outcomes: provide qualified analysis; clarify complex topics; cite credible sources; lead high-signal events such as AMAs.

- Fact Checker (factChecker)
  - Trusted role focused on integrity; can add claim-level annotations with sources, propose corrective labels, and collaborate with moderators; cannot sanction directly.
  - Primary outcomes: annotate claims; surface evidence; propose corrections; increase information quality.

- Moderator (moderator)
  - Responsible for triaging reports, reviewing content, applying policy decisions, issuing warnings and sanctions, handling appeals at first level, and maintaining audit trails.
  - Primary outcomes: enforce policy consistently; meet review SLAs; communicate decisions with policy references.

- Administrator (admin)
  - Governs policies, categories, tags, role assignments, sanctions configuration, and compliance reviews; performs all moderator actions plus administrative operations.
  - Primary outcomes: maintain governance; calibrate policies; ensure compliance; approve sensitive operations (e.g., data exports) in line with policy.

### Representative Use Cases
- Public-interest debate: A member starts a thread on election policy; verifiedMembers provide expert context; factCheckers annotate claims; moderators enforce civility and rules with transparent outcomes.
- Fast misinformation response: A viral claim is reported; factCheckers propose annotations; moderators apply interim labels and review within accelerated SLAs.
- Expert Q&A (AMA): A verifiedMember hosts a scheduled session; members submit questions; evidence-backed answers are curated; summaries remain accessible for public reference.
- Policy transparency in enforcement: A sanctioned user receives a rationale with policy references and appeal windows; rationales are visible to the impacted user and auditable by authorized roles.

## Service Scope and Boundaries

### In Scope (Business Capabilities)
- Role-based participation aligned to the roles above with calibrated privileges and accountability.
- Threaded discussions (posts, comments, replies) with reactions and voting; organization by tags, topics, and categories.
- Reporting and moderation workflows with prioritization, interim actions, rationales, and appeal mechanisms.
- Fact-check lifecycle: submission, review, acceptance/rejection, and visible annotations on referenced claims.
- Transparency and audit: policy references with sanctions, appeals outcomes, and role-appropriate audit views.
- Notifications for replies, mentions, moderation decisions, and fact-check updates, respecting user preferences.
- Ethical growth and monetization features (e.g., sponsorships, subscriptions) governed by guardrails that protect civic integrity.

### Boundaries and Operating Principles
- Civic mission first: quality and safety precede raw engagement or virality.
- Evidence-centered dialogue: claims encouraged to reference credible sources; expert contributions are labeled.
- Transparent enforcement: actions include rationale, duration, and appeal paths; outcomes follow documented SLAs.
- Inclusivity and accessibility: participation is encouraged across backgrounds, languages, and abilities, within community norms and policies.

### High-Level Interaction Flow
```mermaid
graph LR
  subgraph "Public Participation"
    U["Members & Verified Members"] --> P["Posts & Comments"]
    P --> R["Report Content Action"]
    P --> N["Notifications to Followers"]
    P --> T["Topic & Category Organization"]
  end
  subgraph "Quality & Integrity"
    V["Fact Checkers"] --> F["Fact-Check Annotations"]
    F --> P
    R --> M["Moderation Review Queue"]
    M --> E["Enforcement & Appeals"]
  end
  subgraph "Governance"
    A["Administrators"] --> S["Policies, Roles, Settings"]
    S -.-> M
    S -.-> T
  end
```

## Business Model (Why, Revenue Strategy, Growth Plan, Success Metrics)

### Why This Service Exists
- Problem: Civic discussion spaces often degrade into low-signal debate, misinformation, and harassment, discouraging participation and expert input.
- Opportunity: Combining open dialogue with verifiable expertise and structured fact-checking can materially improve discourse quality and civic literacy.
- Differentiation: Role-based trust layers (verified experts and fact checkers), transparent enforcement with measurable SLAs, and annotation-first handling of claims distinguish civicDebateBoard from generic forums and social feeds.

### Revenue Strategy (How)
- Primary: Ethical sponsorships of civic topics with strict conflict-of-interest guardrails and clear disclosure labels.
- Secondary: Organizational subscriptions for curated debates, AMAs, and research initiatives with enhanced moderation support.
- Tertiary: Community memberships providing perks (topic curation, early access, recognition badges) without pay-to-speak or pay-to-amplify mechanics.
- Guardrails: No targeted political ads; no pay-for-reach; mandatory sponsorship disclosures; strong separation between editorial independence and sponsorship.

### What This Service Delivers (Business Operations)
- Evidence-centered civic debate with role accountability and annotated claims.
- Structured policy and enforcement workflows that provide consistent, explainable outcomes with auditable rationales.
- Transparent public-interest programming (e.g., expert Q&A series) that remains accessible as a knowledge resource.
- Ethical monetization that supports the mission without compromising discourse integrity or safety.

### Growth Plan
- Acquisition: Partnerships with universities, think tanks, public libraries, NGOs, journalist networks, and local governments; organic growth from high-quality public-interest threads and expert programming.
- Activation and Retention: Onboarding that encourages citation-backed contributions; scheduled expert sessions; recognition programs for constructive participation and verified expertise.
- Network Effects: Topic following and notifications; recurring event series; durable knowledge artifacts (accepted fact checks, AMA summaries) that drive inbound interest.

### Success Metrics and KPIs
- Reach and Engagement: MAU/DAU, session frequency, and time-to-first-meaningful-response on public-interest threads.
- Quality and Integrity: Share of posts with citations; fact-check turnaround; accepted vs. contested annotations; rate of corrected or retracted claims.
- Safety and Trust: SLA adherence in moderation and appeals; user satisfaction with enforcement communications; reduction in repeat violations.
- Sustainability: Sponsorship revenue by topic (with disclosures), institutional subscription retention, membership conversion and churn.

## Assumptions and Constraints

### Assumptions
- Roles and Identity: Users authenticate and can be associated with one or more of the defined roles with auditable transitions (e.g., member → verifiedMember).
- Policy Governance: Content rules, sanctions, priorities, and appeals are governed by documented policies that can be updated with oversight.
- Time Sensitivity: Certain threads (e.g., election or emergency-related) require elevated review priority and faster turnaround than standard discussions.
- International Participation: Users participate across time zones; timestamps and notices align to user locale for clarity.

### Constraints
- Safety Over Virality: Business processes privilege community safety and integrity over growth tactics that increase harm risk.
- Transparency Obligation: Enforcement communications must include rationales with policy references; appeals must produce documented outcomes.
- Ethical Monetization: Revenue activities cannot bias discourse or undermine safety and independence.
- Privacy and Compliance: Data rights and legal obligations are honored per applicable jurisdictions; security expectations are treated as business obligations.

### EARS-Formatted Operating Constraints
- THE service SHALL include policy references and human-readable rationales with all sanctions visible to the impacted user.
- WHERE sponsorship is present, THE service SHALL label sponsored sessions and SHALL disclose sponsor identity to participants in all related surfaces.
- IF an expert-tagged post by a verifiedMember is found materially inaccurate, THEN THE service SHALL require correction or visible annotation prior to further amplification.
- WHILE a discussion is under active appeal, THE service SHALL preserve evidence and SHALL restrict irreversible enforcement until appeal resolution except where safety risk requires immediate action.
- THE service SHALL reserve high-priority triage for public-interest and time-sensitive topics during defined civic windows (e.g., election periods) with accelerated response targets.
- WHEN notifications are generated for policy decisions or annotations, THE service SHALL deliver them within the published timeframe and SHALL honor user preferences except where notices are mandatory.

## Out of Scope
To keep the vision coherent and delivery focused, the following are out of scope in the current planning horizon:
- Frontend UI/UX specifications, visual design systems, and screen layouts.
- Technical implementation details such as APIs, database schemas, infrastructure choices, or deployment topologies.
- Paid amplification mechanisms (pay-for-reach, targeted political ads) or monetization that could bias civic discourse.
- Real-time voice or video townhalls; the focus is asynchronous and near-synchronous text with notifications.
- Third-party data brokerage or resale of user data.

---

All content in this overview expresses business requirements and expectations only; technical implementation decisions (including architecture, APIs, and data models) remain at the discretion of the development team. For deeper market context, consult the [Market Problem and Value Proposition](./02-market-problem-and-value-proposition.md). For detailed capability rules and validations, consult the [Functional Requirements Specification](./06-functional-requirements.md). For sustainability and measurement details, consult the [Business Model and Analytics Strategy](./10-business-model-and-analytics.md).

# Market Problem and Value Proposition — civicDebateBoard

## Problem Statement
Civic discourse online is undermined by low signal-to-noise ratios, persistent misinformation, harassment, and fragmented conversations that fail to converge on clarity. Mainstream social feeds optimize for virality and novelty, not deliberative quality. Generic forums depend on inconsistent volunteer moderation without evidence workflows. Stakeholders lack shared accountability mechanisms that elevate expertise and protect participants.

Role-based pains observed across civic communities:

- Members (general participants)
  - Encounter hostility, brigading, and low-trust environments that deter participation and reduce willingness to share nuanced perspectives.
  - Lack reliable tools to follow civic topics, bookmark complex threads, and surface credible sources amid noise.
  - Experience inconsistent enforcement, leading to perceptions of unfairness and disengagement.

- Verified Members (identity- or expertise-verified participants)
  - Struggle to make qualified contributions visible without being drowned out by engagement-biased ranking or low-quality replies.
  - Face higher scrutiny with limited affordances to demonstrate expertise (e.g., expert tags with context and accountability).

- Fact Checkers (trusted integrity role)
  - Lack in-platform tools to attach claim-level annotations with citations and transparent ratings (e.g., true, needs context, misleading, false).
  - Experience friction collaborating with moderators; proposed corrections are slow to propagate or hard to discover.

- Moderators (community safety role)
  - Overwhelmed by report volumes without standardized evidence intake, triage SLAs, or audit trails for consistent decisions and appeals.
  - Encounter accusations of bias without transparent policy scaffolding or publishable enforcement metrics.

- Admins (governance role)
  - Need configurable policies, categories, and sanctions with clear oversight for compliance and election-related protections.
  - Require partner-ready governance artifacts and transparency logs to maintain institutional trust.

Underlying structural causes:
- Engagement-first incentives that amplify outrage and novelty rather than verifiable substance.
- Insufficient role differentiation that fails to elevate credible expertise or structure integrity work.
- Missing claim-level evidence mechanisms making corrections adversarial and hard to track.
- Opaque moderation without consistent rationales, timelines, or appeal visibility.

civicDebateBoard addresses these pains by centering deliberation quality, role-based accountability, and transparent governance so that open participation can coexist with trust, safety, and evidence.

## Market Context and Trends
Persistent and accelerating trends intensify demand for a purpose-built civic debate platform:

- Trust & Safety Maturation: Movement from reactive takedowns to policy-led enforcement with auditable rationale, SLAs, and appeal processes demanded by regulators and civil society.
- Election Integrity Focus: Recurring election cycles elevate risks of misinformation, voter suppression narratives, and coordinated manipulation; stakeholders require rapid, auditable responses.
- Role-Based Communities: Professional networks and QA platforms demonstrate the value of role differentiation (experts, moderators, reviewers) to improve signal quality and accountability.
- Evidence-Seeking Behavior: Audiences increasingly look for citations and context, favoring spaces that reward substantiated claims over performative engagement.
- Ethical Monetization: Preference for models that do not rely on polarization or sensitive microtargeting; institutions seek credible venues for public-interest dialogues.
- Compliance & Platform Accountability: Privacy and platform rules (e.g., GDPR-like regimes and election-related guidelines) drive expectations for auditability, transparency logs, and rights-respecting processes.

Opportunity emerges where open participation meets evidence-backed, role-accountable debate with measurable transparency.

## Competitive Landscape
Adjacent categories offer partial solutions but do not integrate deliberation depth, trust mechanisms, and scalable safety operations in one cohesive service.

| Category | Strengths | Gaps vs civicDebateBoard | Implication |
|---------|-----------|--------------------------|-------------|
| Mainstream Social Networks | Reach, real-time updates | Engagement-first ranking, weak role differentiation, opaque moderation, externalized fact-checks | Poor fit for sustained, evidence-led debate |
| Traditional Forums/Subforums | Topic organization, community ownership | Inconsistent moderation, minimal evidence workflows, fragmented appeals | Quality variance; low auditability |
| Q&A/Knowledge Platforms | Reputation systems, focus on accuracy | Not optimized for multi-perspective civic debate or time-bounded events; limited misinformation surge handling | Insufficient for dynamic civic contexts |
| News Comments & Publisher Communities | Article context | Fragmented across sites, minimal transparency for enforcement, weak cross-thread continuity | Limited network effects for civic discourse |
| Specialized Fact-Checking Sites | High-quality fact checks | Not interactive platforms; limited integration into ongoing debates; no role-based community | Lacks participatory debate mechanics |

Positioning summary:
- Competes on deliberation quality, role accountability, and integrated evidence workflows, not on raw audience size or entertainment value.
- Designed for public-interest partners (NGOs, universities, media, local governments) seeking credible civic dialogues with transparent governance.

## Differentiators and Core Value Proposition
civicDebateBoard differentiates through a role-enabled, evidence-forward, transparency-first model tailored to civic conversations.

- Role Differentiation as a First-Class Concept
  - Members: Clear accountability with rate limits and self-moderation tools to support healthy dialogue.
  - Verified Members: Expert-tagged content, structured AMAs, calibrated trust signals, and heightened accountability standards.
  - Fact Checkers: Claim-level annotations with citations, ratings, and transparency notes; collaborative pathways to moderators.
  - Moderators: Policy-backed triage queues, evidence handling, sanctions catalog, and audit trails for explainable decisions.
  - Admins: Governance configuration, policy/sanction management, role assignments, and compliance oversight suitable for civic contexts.

- Evidence-Centric Conversation Mechanics
  - Claim-level annotation lifecycle (proposal, review, accepted/contested), citation surfacing, and contextual transparency to reduce misinformation persistence.
  - Topic/category structures aligned to public-interest themes for sustained discovery and coherent debate continuity.

- Transparency and Accountability by Design
  - Visible policy references accompanying enforcement outcomes, auditable appeals, and publishable transparency logs for aggregated moderation metrics.
  - Clear conflict-of-interest handling for reviewers and fact checkers to reinforce perceived fairness.

- Safety Without Engagement Maximization
  - Healthy discourse outcomes prioritized over raw engagement: resolved debates, consensus markers, correction adoption.
  - Configurable rate limits and thresholds designed to reduce harassment and brigading while preserving legitimate participation.

- Institutional Value
  - Safe, auditable venue for civic partners to host debates, AMAs, and educational series with measurable integrity signals and trust-building transparency.

Value proposition statement:
- Enable high-trust, evidence-backed civic discussions that are transparent, role-accountable, and operationally sustainable—improving discourse quality and community legitimacy for members, institutions, and the broader public.

Mermaid mapping of pains to differentiators:

```mermaid
graph LR
  subgraph "User Pains"
    P1["Low Signal-to-Noise"]
    P2["Misinformation Persistence"]
    P3["Hostility & Brigading"]
    P4["Opaque Moderation"]
    P5["Expert Voices Drowned Out"]
  end
  subgraph "civicDebateBoard Differentiators"
    D1["Role Differentiation"]
    D2["Claim-Level Annotations"]
    D3["Transparent Enforcement"]
    D4["Safety & Rate Limits"]
    D5["Expert Affordances(AMAs,Tags)"]
  end
  P1 --> D1
  P1 --> D5
  P2 --> D2
  P2 --> D3
  P3 --> D4
  P4 --> D3
  P5 --> D1
  P5 --> D5
```

## Risks and Mitigations
The civic debate domain includes operational, reputational, legal, and growth risks. Mitigations emphasize governance, standard operating procedures, and role clarity.

- Cold Start and Network Effects
  - Risk: Difficulty seeding quality discussions without initial critical mass.
  - Mitigations: Partner-led topic launches (universities, NGOs, councils), scheduled expert AMAs, early emphasis on fact-check visibility and topic curation.

- Abuse, Harassment, and Coordinated Manipulation
  - Risk: Targeted brigading during sensitive events leading to participant attrition.
  - Mitigations: Configurable rate limits, graduated sanctions, severity-based triage, conflict-of-interest rules, and transparent enforcement communication.

- Misinformation and Defamation
  - Risk: Legal and reputational exposure from persistent false claims.
  - Mitigations: Claim-level annotations, corrections workflow, visibility labels, and verifiable sources coupled with auditable review outcomes.

- Perception of Bias
  - Risk: Allegations that moderation or fact-checking favors particular viewpoints.
  - Mitigations: Public policy documentation, consistent SLAs, independence in appeals, conflict-of-interest disclosures, and aggregate transparency reporting.

- Compliance Exposure
  - Risk: Failure to meet privacy, election-related, or platform accountability obligations.
  - Mitigations: Governance reviews, consent/rights management, auditability, incident response readiness, and policy updates aligned to civic timelines.

- Monetization Misalignment
  - Risk: Revenue mechanisms incentivizing polarizing content or undermining trust.
  - Mitigations: Ethics-aligned sponsorships/subscriptions, bans on sensitive microtargeting, and guardrails tying revenue to quality outcomes.

- Resource Constraints for Moderation and Fact-Checking
  - Risk: Queues outpace reviewer capacity during peak civic events.
  - Mitigations: Priority-tier routing, partner escalations for P0/P1 civic topics, scheduled volunteer fact-checker rotations, and temporary amplification dampening until review.

- Community Capture by Factions
  - Risk: Dominant groups discourage diverse participation and suppress minority voices.
  - Mitigations: Topic diversity goals, proactive outreach to underrepresented experts, fair-use rate limits, and anti-manipulation rules.

EARS-formatted governance guardrails:
- THE governance model SHALL require conflict-of-interest disclosures for moderators and factCheckers on assigned cases.
- WHEN a civic event enters a designated election window, THE enforcement process SHALL apply elevated SLAs and SHALL prioritize election-integrity categories over standard items.
- IF monetization experiments degrade civic quality metrics beyond thresholds, THEN THE business operations SHALL pause or terminate the experiment and document remediation steps.
- WHERE partner-hosted dialogues occur, THE community operations team SHALL display sponsorship labels and SHALL preserve editorial independence.
- WHILE appeal review is pending, THE enforcement process SHALL preserve evidence and SHALL avoid irreversible actions unless safety requires immediate measures.

## Success Metrics Alignment
Success is defined by outcomes that reflect high-quality, trusted civic discourse and durable institutional credibility. Metrics emphasize quality, trust, safety, and mission-aligned growth rather than raw engagement volume.

- THE civicDebateBoard SHALL achieve ≥ 90% triage SLA attainment for critical severity reports during designated election windows.

# User Roles and Authentication Requirements for civicDebateBoard

Business requirements for authentication, authorization, user roles and permissions, token/session behavior, account lifecycle, and auditability for the civicDebateBoard service. Business scope only; all technical implementation decisions (architecture, APIs, database design, cryptography choices, storage mechanisms) belong to the development team. Describes WHAT the system must do in business terms, not HOW to build it.

Terminology
- “the system”: the civicDebateBoard service
- “user”: a human end-user operating an account
- “session”: a login state tied to a device and a token pair

Related context
- Functional capabilities: [Functional Requirements Specification](./06-functional-requirements.md)
- Safety policies: [Content Moderation and Safety Policies](./07-content-moderation-and-safety-policies.md)
- Security and privacy: [Security, Privacy, and Compliance Requirements](./09-security-privacy-and-compliance.md)

## 1) Definitions and Role Overview

- member: Authenticated community participant who can create and manage own posts and comments, react and vote, follow topics, bookmark, report content, and manage account settings under rate limits and community rules.
- verifiedMember: Identity- or expertise-verified participant with elevated trust level; may create expert-tagged posts, host AMAs, face higher content accountability, enjoy fewer rate limits, and bypass certain pre-moderation queues while remaining subject to all policies.
- factChecker: Trusted role allowed to add fact-check annotations, cite sources, flag misleading claims for review, propose corrections, and generate transparency notes; cannot apply sanctions directly.
- moderator: Role responsible for triaging reports, reviewing content, applying policy decisions, editing/removing violating content, issuing warnings and sanctions, handling appeals within scope, and maintaining community health.
- admin: Top-level role managing platform-wide policies, categories, tags, feature toggles, role assignments, sanctions configuration, data export approvals, and compliance reviews; can perform all moderator actions plus administrative operations.

EARS global principle
- THE civicDebateBoard service SHALL protect accounts, content integrity, and community safety through role-based access control, tokenized sessions, and auditable decision-making.

## 2) Authentication Requirements

### 2.1 Registration
- WHEN a visitor provides required registration attributes (email and password), THE system SHALL create a pending account and send a verification message.
- THE system SHALL require email uniqueness per account.
- THE system SHALL enforce password policy at creation (see 2.5 Password Policy and Reset).
- IF the email is already in use, THEN THE system SHALL reject registration with a clear, non-enumerating message.
- WHERE legal age or jurisdictional constraints apply, THE system SHALL require age attestation and reject accounts that fail attestation.
- THE system SHALL limit registration attempts to a maximum of 5 per IP within 1 hour and 2 per email within 24 hours.
- IF registration throttling thresholds are exceeded, THEN THE system SHALL delay or block further attempts for the applicable cool-down period (minimum 1 hour).

### 2.2 Email Verification
- WHEN a registration completes, THE system SHALL send a verification link with a validity of 24 hours.
- WHEN a user requests re-send, THE system SHALL allow up to 3 re-sends within 24 hours.
- IF the verification link is expired or invalid, THEN THE system SHALL deny verification and provide a re-send path.
- WHILE the account is unverified, THE system SHALL restrict posting and interaction capabilities to read-only and profile completion functions.
- WHEN email verification succeeds, THE system SHALL mark the account as verified and lift unverified restrictions.

### 2.3 Login
- WHEN a user submits email and password, THE system SHALL validate credentials and respond within 2 seconds under normal load.
- IF the credentials are invalid, THEN THE system SHALL reject login and increment a failed-attempt counter.
- IF there are 10 failed login attempts for the same account within 15 minutes, THEN THE system SHALL lock login attempts for that account for 15 minutes and notify the user via the primary email.
- WHERE multi-factor verification is required by policy or risk, THE system SHALL challenge with a secondary factor before establishing a session (see 2.8 Multi-Factor Authentication).
- WHEN login succeeds, THE system SHALL establish a session associated with a specific device context and issue tokens per Section 4.

### 2.4 Logout
- WHEN a user invokes logout on a device, THE system SHALL immediately invalidate the corresponding session for that device.
- WHEN a user invokes “logout from all devices”, THE system SHALL invalidate all sessions and tokens for that user within 60 seconds.

### 2.5 Password Policy and Reset
- THE system SHALL enforce password complexity at creation and change: minimum 10 characters; must include at least 3 of the following: uppercase letters, lowercase letters, digits, symbols; shall not contain the email local-part; shall not be one of the last 5 used passwords.
- WHEN a user requests password reset, THE system SHALL send a reset link valid for 60 minutes.
- IF a reset token is expired, revoked, or invalid, THEN THE system SHALL deny the reset and allow issuing a new token subject to rate limits (max 3 per 24 hours per account).
- WHEN a password is successfully reset, THE system SHALL revoke all existing sessions and require re-login on all devices.
- WHEN a user changes password while authenticated, THE system SHALL enforce the same complexity and reuse rules and SHALL revoke all other device sessions within 60 seconds.

### 2.6 Session Management
- THE system SHALL associate each session with a user, a device context, and a token pair with independent lifetimes (see Section 4).
- THE system SHALL allow up to 10 concurrent active sessions per user by default.
- WHERE an organization or policy sets a lower limit, THE system SHALL enforce the configured maximum sessions per user.
- WHEN a session exceeds its refresh lifetime, THE system SHALL require full login to re-establish a session.
- WHILE a session is valid, THE system SHALL honor access tokens for authorization checks within their lifetime.

### 2.7 Device Management and Revocation
- THE system SHALL maintain a list of active sessions and device contexts visible to the account owner (device name, last activity time, approximate location, and creation time) without exposing sensitive identifiers.
- WHEN the account owner revokes a device session, THE system SHALL invalidate that session’s tokens within 60 seconds and block further refresh for that session.
- WHEN suspicious activity is detected (e.g., impossible travel, many failed refresh attempts), THE system SHALL flag the session for review and may require re-authentication on next action.

### 2.8 Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)
- WHERE policy, risk scoring, or user preference requires MFA, THE system SHALL require a second factor in addition to password before session establishment.
- THE system SHALL support recovery options appropriate to policy (e.g., backup codes) without prescribing mechanisms; recovery use SHALL be logged in audit trails.
- WHERE a device is marked as trusted, THE system SHALL allow skipping MFA for that device for up to 30 days, after which MFA SHALL be required again.
- IF MFA verification fails 5 times within 15 minutes, THEN THE system SHALL require a cool-down of 15 minutes before another attempt and SHALL notify the account email.

### 2.9 Email Change and Account Recovery
- WHEN a user requests to change the primary email, THE system SHALL verify current authentication, send confirmation to both old and new emails, and require confirmation within 24 hours to complete the change.
- IF email change is not confirmed within 24 hours, THEN THE system SHALL cancel the change and retain the old email.
- WHEN email is changed successfully, THE system SHALL require re-verification of the new email and SHALL revoke all active sessions except the current device session used to complete the change.
- WHEN an account recovery is initiated due to lost email access, THE system SHALL require additional verification steps defined by policy and SHALL limit account functionality until recovery completes.

### 2.10 Session Idle Timeout and Remember Device
- WHILE a session is idle, THE system SHALL expire the interactive session after 30 minutes of inactivity and require re-authentication for further actions, without affecting the refresh token lifetime.
- WHERE a “remember this device” preference is set, THE system SHALL maintain session refresh eligibility for up to 30 days from last credentialed login per Section 4, subject to revocation.
- IF a high-risk action is initiated (e.g., role change, password change), THEN THE system SHALL require recent re-authentication regardless of idle time or remember-device status.

## 3) Role Hierarchy and Permissions

Role scope and escalation model
- THE system SHALL implement a hierarchical permission model where admin encompasses moderator permissions; moderator does not encompass admin; factChecker, verifiedMember, and member are orthogonal in scope except where explicitly extended.
- WHERE a user holds multiple roles, THE system SHALL grant the union of permissions and enforce the strictest accountability and transparency rules that apply to any held role.

Role capabilities (business-level)
- member
  - Create, edit, and delete own posts and comments within edit windows and policy.
  - React, vote, follow topics, bookmark items, and report content.
  - Manage own account and sessions within limits.
- verifiedMember
  - All member capabilities.
  - Create expert-tagged posts; host AMAs; enjoy reduced pre-moderation and rate limits as defined by policy.
  - Elevated accountability: content may require more detailed disclosures where applicable.
- factChecker
  - Add fact-check annotations tied to specific claims; attach sources and confidence levels.
  - Flag misleading claims for review; propose corrections; generate transparency notes.
  - No sanction powers; cannot edit or delete others’ content.
- moderator
  - Review reports and queues; apply policy decisions; edit/remove violating content.
  - Issue warnings, mutes, suspensions within scope; handle appeals at first level.
  - Access limited audit views necessary for case handling.
- admin
  - All moderator capabilities.
  - Manage platform-wide policies, categories, tags, feature toggles, role assignments, sanctions configuration, data export approvals, and compliance reviews.

EARS role controls
- WHEN a member attempts to apply a sanction, THE system SHALL deny the action and display insufficient permission.
- WHEN a factChecker submits a fact-check note, THE system SHALL record it with attribution and route for visibility according to policy.
- WHEN a moderator removes content, THE system SHALL record the reason, policy reference, and notify the content owner.
- WHEN an admin changes a user’s role, THE system SHALL record the actor, old role(s), new role(s), timestamp, and justification and SHALL notify the affected user.

## 4) Token Management (JWT) and Session Expiration Policies

Business requirements for tokenized sessions
- THE system SHALL use JWT for access and refresh tokens.
- THE access token lifetime SHALL be 15 minutes.
- THE refresh token lifetime SHALL be 14 days, with sliding renewal on successful refresh (rotation) up to a maximum of 30 days from last credentialed login.
- WHEN a refresh occurs, THE system SHALL rotate the refresh token and invalidate the previous refresh token.
- IF a previously used refresh token is presented again (reuse), THEN THE system SHALL revoke the corresponding session and require full re-authentication.
- WHEN a user logs out, THE system SHALL invalidate the associated refresh token(s) and disallow further refresh for that session.
- THE JWT payload SHALL include at minimum: userId, role, permissions array suitable for authorization checks, issued-at time, expiry time, and a session identifier.
- WHERE additional security context is configured (e.g., device identifier, risk score), THE system SHALL include business-relevant claims without exposing sensitive personal data.
- THE system SHALL support immediate revocation within 60 seconds for logout-all and device revocation actions.
- WHERE clock skew between clients and the system exists, THE system SHALL allow a tolerance of up to 60 seconds for token validation decisions without extending token lifetimes.

Business obligations for signing key management (non-technical)
- THE system SHALL protect token-signing secrets as confidential business assets with access limited to personnel with a defined business need.
- THE system SHALL rotate token-signing secrets on a regular cadence not to exceed 90 days and upon suspected exposure.
- WHEN a key rotation occurs, THE system SHALL honor active sessions signed by prior keys for a limited overlap window consistent with security policy while ensuring new tokens use the new key.

## 5) Permission Matrix (Actions vs Roles)

Baseline permissions. Rate limits and policy rules still apply. A check mark means “allowed by default,” a cross means “not allowed”; some actions are “Conditional” as noted.

| Action | member | verifiedMember | factChecker | moderator | admin |
|---|---|---|---|---|---|
| Register account | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ |
| Login / Logout | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ |
| View public content | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ |
| Create post | ✅ (rate-limited) | ✅ (reduced limits) | ✅ (within policy) | ✅ | ✅ |
| Create expert-tagged post | ❌ | ✅ | ❌ | ❌ | ✅ (for official posts) |
| Edit own post (within window) | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ |
| Delete own post (within window/policy) | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ |
| Comment on posts | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ |
| Vote/React | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ |
| Follow topics / Bookmark | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ |
| Report content | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ |
| Add fact-check annotation | ❌ | ❌ | ✅ | ✅ (with tag) | ✅ |
| Flag misleading claims for review | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ |
| Propose corrections | ❌ | ❌ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ |
| Edit/remove others’ content | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ✅ | ✅ |
| Issue warnings | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ✅ | ✅ |
| Issue mutes/suspensions | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ✅ (within scope) | ✅ |
| Handle appeals (first level) | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ✅ | ✅ |
| Overturn moderator decision | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ✅ |
| Manage roles and verifications | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ✅ |
| Manage policies/categories/tags | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ✅ |
| Approve data exports | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ✅ |
| Access audit logs (case-limited) | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ✅ (need-to-know) | ✅ (full) |
| Host AMAs | ❌ | ✅ | ❌ | ✅ (official) | ✅ |

Clarifications
- “within window” means within the edit/delete grace windows in the [Functional Requirements Specification](./06-functional-requirements.md).
- “within scope” means within sanction ranges and SLAs in the [Content Moderation and Safety Policies](./07-content-moderation-and-safety-policies.md).

## 6) Authorization Rules and Validation (Business Terms)

General authorization checks
- WHEN an action requires a specific role, THE system SHALL validate that the role is present in the current session’s permissions.
- WHEN content ownership is required (e.g., edit own post), THE system SHALL validate the actor is the content owner and the action is within permitted time windows.
- WHERE actions are rate-limited, THE system SHALL enforce limits per user and per device to prevent abuse.

Conflict-of-interest and sensitive actions
- WHERE an action materially affects another user’s account state (e.g., permanent ban), THE system SHALL require the appropriate role and SHALL capture policy basis and rationale.
- WHERE sanctions beyond 14 days are considered, THE system SHALL require admin review per safety policy documents.

Error-handling
- IF authorization fails, THEN THE system SHALL deny the action with an explanation appropriate to the user’s role and context without revealing sensitive internal details.
- IF ownership validation fails, THEN THE system SHALL deny the action and indicate that only the owner may perform it within the permitted window.

## 7) Account Lifecycle

States (business-level)
- Registered(Unverified)
- Email Verified
- Active
- Verified Member (overlay role state)
- Muted (temporary, limited interactions)
- Suspended (temporary, login allowed only to view notices and appeal)
- Banned (permanent or long-term; login allowed only for appeals if policy allows)
- Deleted (pending grace period) / Hard Deleted
- Appeal Pending (overlay state)
- Dormant (overlay state for inactivity beyond policy threshold)

Transitions and rules
- WHEN registration completes, THE system SHALL place the account in Registered(Unverified).
- WHEN email is verified within 24 hours, THE system SHALL transition to Email Verified.
- WHEN profile minimums are met (if required), THE system SHALL mark the account Active.
- WHERE identity or expertise verification is approved by admins, THE system SHALL grant verifiedMember.
- WHEN a mute sanction is applied, THE system SHALL restrict posting and commenting for the mute duration while allowing read access.
- WHEN a suspension is applied, THE system SHALL restrict all posting and commenting; login is allowed for reviewing notices and filing appeals.
- WHEN a ban is applied, THE system SHALL disable access except appeal functions as policy dictates.
- WHEN a user requests deletion, THE system SHALL place the account in Deleted (pending) with a 30-day grace period for reversal.
- IF the deletion grace period elapses without reversal, THEN THE system SHALL hard delete the account and irreversibly remove personal data subject to legal and audit obligations.
- WHEN an appeal is filed, THE system SHALL mark the case Appeal Pending and pause escalation timelines until a decision is issued.
- WHEN an appeal is granted, THE system SHALL restore the prior permissible state and record the justification.
- WHEN an appeal is denied, THE system SHALL maintain the sanction state and record the justification.
- WHERE an account shows no activity for 12 months, THE system SHALL mark it Dormant and SHALL require re-verification on next login.

Notifications
- THE system SHALL notify users of state changes (verification, sanctions, appeals decisions, deletion, dormancy) using preferred channels per the [Functional Requirements Specification](./06-functional-requirements.md).

## 8) Auditability and Transparency Requirements

- THE system SHALL produce an immutable audit trail for security- and policy-relevant events: registrations, logins, logouts, token refreshes and revocations, password changes/resets, role assignments, sanctions, appeals decisions, email changes, MFA events, and recovery actions.
- THE system SHALL capture for each audited event: actor (user or system), target (user/content), action, timestamp, outcome (success/failure), and justification where applicable.
- WHERE personal data minimization is required, THE system SHALL record only the minimum necessary identifiers.
- WHEN moderators or admins take actions affecting user content or state, THE system SHALL require entering a policy reference and rationale.
- THE system SHALL provide role-appropriate audit access: moderators see case-relevant records; admins can run compliance reviews.
- IF evidence (e.g., screenshots, links) is attached to a moderation action, THEN THE system SHALL preserve references consistent with the [Security, Privacy, and Compliance Requirements](./09-security-privacy-and-compliance.md).

## 9) Non-Functional Expectations for Authentication

- THE system SHALL respond to successful login within 2 seconds under normal load (p95) and 4 seconds under peak load (p95).
- THE system SHALL deliver verification and reset emails within 2 minutes under normal conditions; retries SHALL occur for transient failures for up to 30 minutes.
- THE system SHALL support immediate logout-all and device revocation propagation within 60 seconds p95.
- THE system SHALL enforce rate limits for registration, login, reset, MFA, and recovery flows as defined in Sections 2.1, 2.3, 2.5, and 2.8–2.9.
- WHERE service degradation occurs, THE system SHALL provide clear user-facing messages and safe fallback behaviors without exposing internal details.

## 10) Detailed EARS Acceptance Criteria by Flow

### 10.1 Registration and Verification
- WHEN a user completes the sign-up form with a unique email and compliant password, THE system SHALL create an unverified account and send a verification email within 2 minutes.
- IF the email is already registered, THEN THE system SHALL prevent account creation and present a non-enumerating message.
- IF the verification link is invalid or expired, THEN THE system SHALL refuse verification and allow requesting a new link subject to rate limits.
- WHEN verification is successful, THE system SHALL elevate the account to verified state and unlock standard interactions.

### 10.2 Login, Logout, and Lockout
- WHEN valid credentials are submitted, THE system SHALL issue tokens and create a session in less than 2 seconds.
- IF invalid credentials are submitted, THEN THE system SHALL increment a failure counter and return an error without indicating which field is incorrect.
- IF the account reaches 10 failed attempts in 15 minutes, THEN THE system SHALL impose a 15-minute lockout and notify the user’s email.
- WHEN logout is requested, THE system SHALL invalidate the associated session’s refresh token within 60 seconds.
- WHEN logout-all is requested, THE system SHALL invalidate all sessions for that user within 60 seconds.

### 10.3 Password Reset and Change
- WHEN a reset is requested, THE system SHALL send a reset link valid for 60 minutes and rate-limit to 3 per day per account.
- WHEN a password is reset successfully, THE system SHALL revoke all sessions and require fresh login everywhere.
- IF the new password fails complexity or reuse checks, THEN THE system SHALL reject the change with specific, actionable messages.
- WHEN a password is changed by an authenticated user, THE system SHALL revoke all other device sessions within 60 seconds.

### 10.4 Token Refresh and Reuse Detection
- WHEN an access token expires, THE system SHALL allow refresh using a valid refresh token within its lifetime.
- WHEN a refresh occurs, THE system SHALL rotate the refresh token and issue a new access token.
- IF a refresh token is detected as reused, THEN THE system SHALL revoke the session and require full login.
- WHERE clock skew is present, THE system SHALL tolerate up to 60 seconds skew without extending token lifetime.

### 10.5 Multi-Factor Authentication
- WHEN MFA is required, THE system SHALL prompt for a second factor before completing login.
- IF MFA attempts fail 5 times within 15 minutes, THEN THE system SHALL apply a 15-minute cool-down and notify the account email.
- WHERE a device is marked trusted, THE system SHALL bypass MFA on that device for up to 30 days unless risk signals require re-prompt.

### 10.6 Email Change and Account Recovery
- WHEN a user requests to change the email, THE system SHALL send confirmations to old and new emails and SHALL require confirmation within 24 hours to complete.
- IF the email change is not confirmed within 24 hours, THEN THE system SHALL cancel the change and retain the old email.
- WHEN account recovery is initiated, THE system SHALL restrict sensitive actions until recovery completes and SHALL record recovery steps in the audit trail.

### 10.7 Session Idle Timeout and Re-Authentication for Sensitive Actions
- WHILE a session is idle for 30 minutes, THE system SHALL expire interactive access and require re-authentication for further actions.
- WHEN a sensitive action is attempted (e.g., password change, role change), THE system SHALL require recent re-authentication even if within the idle window.

### 10.8 Authorization by Role
- WHEN an action requires moderator privileges, THE system SHALL permit the action only if the session includes moderator or admin roles.
- WHEN a fact-check annotation is submitted, THE system SHALL record the annotation and attribute it to the factChecker role user.
- IF a user without verifiedMember status attempts to create an expert-tagged post, THEN THE system SHALL deny the action and indicate the verification requirement.

## 11) Diagrams

### 11.1 Authentication and Token Refresh Flow
```mermaid
graph LR
  subgraph "User Device"
    A["Submit Login(Email,Password)"] --> B["Wait For Response"]
    H["Use Access Token For Requests"] --> I{"Access Token Expired?"}
    I -->|"Yes"| J["Send Refresh Token"]
    I -->|"No"| H
  end
  subgraph "civicDebateBoard Service"
    C["Validate Credentials"] --> D{"Account State OK?"}
    D -->|"Yes"| E["Issue Access & Refresh Tokens"]
    D -->|"No"| F["Deny With Reason"]
    K["Validate Refresh Token"] --> L{"Refresh Valid?"}
    L -->|"Yes"| M["Rotate Refresh & Issue New Access"]
    L -->|"No"| F
  end
  A --> C
  E --> B
  B --> H
  J --> K
  M --> H
```

### 11.2 Account Lifecycle Overview
```mermaid
graph LR
  A["Registered(Unverified)"] -->|"Verify Email(<24h)"| B["Email Verified"]
  B -->|"Profile Minimums Met"| C["Active"]
  C -->|"Admin Grants Verification"| D["Verified Member"]
  C -->|"Issue Mute(<=7d)"| E["Muted"]
  C -->|"Issue Suspension(<=30d)"| F["Suspended"]
  C -->|"Ban"| G["Banned"]
  E -->|"Mute Ends"| C
  F -->|"Suspension Ends"| C
  G -->|"Appeal Filed"| H["Appeal Pending"]
  H -->|"Appeal Upheld"| C
  H -->|"Appeal Denied"| G
  C -->|"User Requests Deletion"| I["Deleted(Pending)"]
  I -->|"Grace Ends(30d)"| J["Hard Deleted"]
  I -->|"User Cancels Deletion"| C
  C -->|"No Activity(12mo)"| K["Dormant"]
  K -->|"Login Attempt"| B
```

## 12) Data and Privacy Alignment (Business Terms)

- THE system SHALL minimize personal data exposure in session and audit records consistent with the [Security, Privacy, and Compliance Requirements](./09-security-privacy-and-compliance.md).
- WHERE legal hold or regulatory retention applies, THE system SHALL retain essential audit records without restoring interactive access for deleted or banned accounts.

## 13) Success Criteria

- Complete and correct enforcement of role-based permissions per matrix.
- Reliable session handling with timely revocation and token rotation.
- Clear, testable EARS requirements for all major flows, including MFA, email change, idle timeout, and recovery.
- Alignment with safety policies and compliance documents without prescribing implementation.

# civicDebateBoard — User Personas and Scenarios (Requirement Analysis)

Business requirements only for civicDebateBoard. All technical implementation decisions (architecture, APIs, data models, and infrastructure) belong to the development team. Content defines WHAT outcomes and behaviors are required in business terms.

## Document Scope and Context
- Purpose: Represent real users, their motivations, and end-to-end scenarios that drive unambiguous business requirements for civic discourse.
- Alignment: Complements strategic framing in the [Service Vision and Overview](./01-service-vision-and-overview.md); feeds procedural detail in the [User Flows and Processes](./05-user-flows-and-processes.md); anchors validation rules in the [Functional Requirements](./06-functional-requirements.md).
- Service Prefix: civicDebateBoard
- Roles in Scope: member, verifiedMember, factChecker, moderator, admin
- Tone: Formal, outcome-oriented, policy-aware; excludes UI and technical specifications.

## Personas

### Member
- Summary: Authenticated participant who starts and joins discussions, reacts and votes, follows topics, bookmarks content, reports issues, and manages account settings under rate limits and policy.
- Motivations:
  - Participate in good-faith civic debate to learn and contribute constructively.
  - Find trustworthy, timely information and see quality signals.
  - Receive relevant updates about followed topics, authors, and threads.
- Goals:
  - Publish compliant posts and comments that remain visible.
  - Get meaningful responses and see consensus signals (votes, helpful reactions).
  - Curate a personalized feed via follows and bookmarks.
- Behaviors:
  - Creates drafts, edits shortly after posting, and reports harmful or off-policy content.
  - Subscribes to notifications; manages preferences; returns to long threads via bookmarks.
- Constraints:
  - Must verify email to publish or report; subject to role-based rate limits and sanctions when applicable.
- Pain Points and Anti-Goals:
  - Pain: Low-signal replies and brigading drown out substance; uncertainty about moderation outcomes.
  - Anti-Goals: Does not want to manage complex settings; does not want to lose drafts or be rate-limited without clear timing.
- Information Needs:
  - Clear status of posts/comments (published, pending, held); transparent moderation decisions; visible cooldown timers.
- Definition of Success:
  - Content publish completes within seconds; replies trigger timely notifications; reports produce visible outcomes; preferences persist and apply consistently.

### Verified Member
- Summary: Identity- or expertise-verified participant with elevated trust and accountability; can publish expert-tagged content and host structured Q&A sessions.
- Motivations:
  - Share qualified expertise with accountability; reduce friction from pre-moderation; build public credibility.
- Goals:
  - Publish expert posts discoverable as authoritative; host AMAs with structured Q&A; cite credible sources.
- Behaviors:
  - Provides sources with claims; maintains higher accuracy standards; engages respectfully across threads.
- Constraints:
  - Elevated accountability; some actions subject to audit; relaxed rate limits relative to members but full policy compliance.
- Pain Points and Anti-Goals:
  - Pain: Expertise drowned by low-signal responses; unnecessary pre-moderation holds during urgent civic events.
  - Anti-Goals: Avoids forced editorial control by sponsors or admins.
- Information Needs:
  - Expert-tag visibility; AMA scheduling status; annotation or label status on their content.
- Definition of Success:
  - Expert posts and AMAs achieve high-quality engagement with minimal false-positive holds; annotations and corrections are visible and discoverable.

### Fact Checker
- Summary: Trusted role adding fact-check annotations with citations, flagging misleading claims for review, proposing corrections, and creating transparency notes; cannot sanction.
- Motivations:
  - Improve information quality, context, and verifiability; reduce misinformation persistence.
- Goals:
  - Attach annotations with sources; elevate critical misleading claims quickly to moderation.
- Behaviors:
  - Adds structured notes including claim excerpts, rating, sources, and explanation; proposes labels that can affect distribution once confirmed by moderation.
- Constraints:
  - No direct sanctions; requires moderator/admin confirmation for enforcement-affecting labels; recusal on conflicts.
- Pain Points and Anti-Goals:
  - Pain: Limited visibility or delayed review of annotations on fast-moving threads; unclear status of proposed labels.
  - Anti-Goals: Being perceived as partisan; losing transparency into annotation outcomes.
- Information Needs:
  - Annotation visibility state; review status; acceptance/rejection reasons; conflict-of-interest routing confirmations.
- Definition of Success:
  - Annotations surface contextually; proposals reviewed within SLAs; authors and readers see clear evidence and status.

### Moderator
- Summary: Triage reports, review content, apply policy decisions, edit/remove violations, issue warnings and sanctions, handle appeals within scope, and maintain community health.
- Motivations:
  - Fair, consistent, transparent enforcement; meet review SLAs; reduce repeat violations.
- Goals:
  - Process queues efficiently; apply proportionate actions with rationale; escalate correctly; minimize overturned decisions.
- Behaviors:
  - Triage by severity; consult policy references; notify affected parties with concise reasons; maintain audit trails.
- Constraints:
  - Must follow escalation rules; avoid conflicts of interest; respect auditability and evidence handling.
- Pain Points and Anti-Goals:
  - Pain: Report floods and mass-report brigading; incomplete evidence; unclear precedence.
  - Anti-Goals: Silent enforcement without rationale; inconsistent decisions across reviewers.
- Information Needs:
  - Consolidated case evidence; prior history; annotation context; SLA timers; conflict-of-interest alerts.
- Definition of Success:
  - Queue latency within SLA; low appeal reversal rate; clear communications with policy references.

### Admin
- Summary: Manages platform policies, categories, tags, feature toggles, role assignments, sanctions configuration, data export approvals, and compliance reviews; can perform all moderator actions.
- Motivations:
  - Ensure governance, safety, compliance, and sustainable growth.
- Goals:
  - Configure policies and taxonomies; manage roles; approve sensitive exports; oversee compliance and audits.
- Behaviors:
  - Assigns roles; updates sanctions and policies; reviews audits; activates elevated-protection windows (election/crisis).
- Constraints:
  - Operates under legal and governance obligations; high accountability in audit logs; separation from editorial influence.
- Pain Points and Anti-Goals:
  - Pain: Policy drift across teams; emergency protections not activating quickly enough; perception of bias.
  - Anti-Goals: Monetization that compromises discourse integrity; opaque policy changes.
- Information Needs:
  - Change impact summaries; compliance status; transparency reports; live SLA adherence.
- Definition of Success:
  - Policies and roles reflect current needs; community health metrics improve; compliance reviews pass with minimal exceptions.

## Primary Scenarios (Happy Paths)

### 1) Member publishes and engages
- Narrative: A member drafts a substantive discussion within rate limits, selects relevant topics and tags, and publishes. If no pre-moderation is required, the post appears instantly. The member follows the thread, receives notifications for replies, and responds. The thread remains discoverable via topics and search.
- Business Rules: Email verification is required to publish; content must conform to policy; rate limits apply; edits allowed in a short window (e.g., 15 minutes) without review; material changes after the window may require review.
- Success Indicators: Publication ≤ 3 seconds; notifications ≤ 1 minute for direct replies; discoverability by selected topics.

### 2) Verified Member hosts an expert Q&A (AMA)
- Narrative: A verifiedMember schedules and posts an expert session tagged as "expert". Questions from members are collected; the host answers and cites sources. A summary note closes the session; the thread remains archived.
- Business Rules: Expert tagging restricted to verifiedMember and above; standard policies and rate limits apply; tagging may increase prominence but never exempts policy.
- Success Indicators: On-time start; proper question routing; visible summary; high-quality engagement with minimal intervention.

### 3) Fact Checker annotates a claim
- Narrative: A factChecker identifies a claim in a popular post, attaches an annotation with citations, and proposes a label such as "unsupported". Readers see the contextual note and sources. A moderator reviews and confirms the label; the author is notified and may revise.
- Business Rules: Annotations are non-destructive; proposed enforcement-affecting labels require moderator confirmation.
- Success Indicators: Annotation visible in ≤ 3 seconds; review completed within SLA; readers engage with sources.

### 4) Member reports content; Moderator triages and enforces
- Narrative: A member reports content for misinformation or harassment. The system assigns severity and routes to queues. A moderator reviews context and history, applies a proportionate action (dismiss, edit with note, warning, temporary mute, suspension), and logs rationale. Reporter and author are notified.
- Business Rules: Reporter identity remains confidential to the author; sanctions follow configured ladders; appeals are available within a defined window.
- Success Indicators: High-severity acknowledgement in minutes; decisions communicated clearly; low reversal rate on appeal.

### 5) Admin manages categories and roles
- Narrative: An admin creates categories for civic events, updates taxonomies, and assigns factChecker status to a qualified user. Changes take effect quickly and are audited. Affected users are notified.
- Business Rules: Role changes require justification; taxonomy changes propagate to discovery and subscriptions; audits capture who, what, when, and why.
- Success Indicators: No disruption to existing content; new categories visible; role changes reflect instantly in permissions.

### 6) Member follows topics and receives updates
- Narrative: A member follows civic topics. New posts in those topics trigger notifications and update a personalized feed. The member can unfollow at any time with immediate effect.
- Business Rules: Follow capacity and rate limits apply; notification preferences are user-configurable.
- Success Indicators: Timely, relevant notifications; accurate feed reflecting follow/unfollow.

### 7) Author adopts a fact-check correction
- Narrative: An author receives a notification that a claim in their post has an accepted annotation rated "misleading". The author revises the content with sources and submits. The revision is accepted; the label is updated to "corrected" and the post remains visible with a transparency note.
- Business Rules: Correction path available to authors; material edits may require review; transparency note persists.
- Success Indicators: Correction acknowledged within minutes; label updated; readers can see correction context.

### 8) Digest notifications for busy topics
- Narrative: A member opts into daily digests for a category. The system aggregates updates and sends a digest. The member can switch back to instant notifications.
- Business Rules: Respect category preferences and quiet hours; deduplicate events; configurable cadence.
- Success Indicators: Digest contains relevant items; opt-in/out takes effect within 1 minute.

### 9) Moderator conflict-of-interest recusal
- Narrative: A case assignment engine detects a potential conflict (recent sanctioning of the same author by the same moderator). The case is reassigned; the system records recusal.
- Business Rules: Independence rule enforced for assignments and appeals.
- Success Indicators: Reassignment within minutes; audit contains recusal reason and timestamp.

### 10) Election window activation
- Narrative: Admin activates an elevated-protection window for an upcoming election. Reports in relevant categories are prioritized with faster SLAs; political-content labels are enabled; transparency logs note the activation window.
- Business Rules: Election windows elevate certain categories; labels and prioritization apply during activation period.
- Success Indicators: Priority routing verified; SLA compliance improved on election-related items; visibility of labels.

## Secondary and Special Scenarios (Edge Cases)

### Editing window exceeded
- Narrative: A member attempts to edit after the self-edit window. A revision request path is offered; material changes queue for review.
- Expected Outcome: Immediate denial with rationale; optional revision request tracked; visibility preserved until decision.

### Rate limit reached during surge
- Narrative: A member hits post or comment limits during high-traffic events.
- Expected Outcome: Clear cooldown timing; draft preserved; automatic re-attempt guidance where applicable.

### Email not verified but attempting to publish
- Narrative: An authenticated but unverified user tries to publish or report.
- Expected Outcome: Action blocked with instructions to verify; draft and selections preserved for completion post-verification.

### Suspended user content visibility
- Narrative: Past content of a suspended user is accessed.
- Expected Outcome: Labels or limited visibility applied per policy; audit trail intact.

### Fact-checker conflict of interest
- Narrative: A factChecker attempts to annotate a close collaborator’s content.
- Expected Outcome: Disclosure required; annotation held; routed to independent reviewer.

### Moderator conflict-of-interest recusal
- Narrative: A moderator is assigned a report involving a recently sanctioned author.
- Expected Outcome: Automatic reassignment; recusal captured in audit.

### Appeals window and reinstatement
- Narrative: A sanctioned user appeals within the allowed window.
- Expected Outcome: Acknowledgement with tracking ID; independent review within SLA; clear outcome notification with rationale.

### Multi-device session revocation
- Narrative: A member revokes all device sessions due to suspected account sharing.
- Expected Outcome: Active sessions terminate within a minute; re-authentication required across devices.

### Timezone and localization handling
- Narrative: A traveling user views timestamps across timezones.
- Expected Outcome: Timestamps reflect preference with clear offsets; original post time remains interpretable.

### Duplicate reports and stale links
- Narrative: Multiple users report the same content; a link in the content is stale.
- Expected Outcome: Reports merged; stale link warning provided to author; prioritization considers deduplication.

### Long thread management
- Narrative: A thread exceeds typical length and depth.
- Expected Outcome: Participants can navigate with summaries and structured context in business terms; moderation tools highlight hotspots.

### Cross-posting and archived topics
- Narrative: Content cross-posted between related categories; topic later archived.
- Expected Outcome: Cross-post references remain consistent; archived topics retain read access; posting disabled in archived topics.

## Abuse and Misuse Scenarios

### Coordinated brigading and vote manipulation
- Behavior: New or low-trust accounts mass-upvote or downvote to distort consensus.
- Mitigations: Weighted voting by trust signals; burst-limiting; correlation detection; moderator review flags.
- Expected Outcomes: Reduced manipulative impact; investigation trails available.

### Misinformation campaigns in civic contexts
- Behavior: Misleading claims surge during elections or emergencies.
- Mitigations: Priority routing to factChecker and moderator; interstitial context; reduced amplification pending review.
- Expected Outcomes: Timely labels and context; preserved legitimate debate.

### Harassment and doxxing
- Behavior: Targeted harassment, threats, or non-consensual personal data sharing.
- Mitigations: Immediate removal of personal data; protective actions (mutes/suspensions); targeted reporting paths.
- Expected Outcomes: Rapid protection; proportionate sanctions; comprehensive audit.

### Spam and link farming
- Behavior: Low-quality promotional links at scale; link shorteners with tracking.
- Mitigations: Strict rate limits; link reputation checks; auto-collapsing repetitive posts; escalating sanctions.
- Expected Outcomes: Reduced spam visibility; legitimate links unaffected.

### Sockpuppetry and duplicate accounts
- Behavior: Multiple accounts used to evade sanctions or fake consensus.
- Mitigations: Behavioral analytics; stricter new-account limits; consolidated enforcement across linked accounts per policy.
- Expected Outcomes: Evasion curtailed; sanctions applied across linked accounts.

### Malicious or bad-faith reporting
- Behavior: Repeatedly reporting compliant content to burden moderation.
- Mitigations: Reporter reputation factoring; cooldowns for false reporting; sanctions for abuse.
- Expected Outcomes: Lower false-positive load; preserved reporter functionality for good-faith users.

### Sanction evasion attempts
- Behavior: Editing to obscure violations; deleting evidence; obfuscation.
- Mitigations: Immutable audit snapshots; pre-removal capture; post-edit re-checks; pattern detection.
- Expected Outcomes: Evasion ineffective; accountability preserved.

### Deepfake or synthetic media
- Behavior: AI-generated media used to mislead.
- Mitigations: Labeling workflows; request for provenance; fact-check affinity routing; temporary deamplification pending review.
- Expected Outcomes: Harm reduced; clear labels; source transparency.

### Mass-report brigading
- Behavior: Coordinated campaigns to mass-report targeted users to silence them.
- Mitigations: Deduplication, reputation weighting, and anomaly detection; independence rules for reviewers.
- Expected Outcomes: Minimized abuse; protected speech for compliant content; auditability of report patterns.

### Astroturfing by coordinated organizations
- Behavior: Coordinated accounts simulate grassroots support.
- Mitigations: Trust scoring, disclosure requirements, and distribution controls when applicable.
- Expected Outcomes: Reduced misleading amplification; transparency labels when disclosures apply.

## Acceptance Criteria (EARS)

All requirements use EARS with descriptions in en-US and keywords in English.

### Core Participation and Posting
- WHEN a verified email member publishes compliant content, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL make the content visible to the community within 3 seconds.
- IF a member attempts to publish without verified email, THEN THE civicDebateBoard SHALL block the action and provide a clear verification path without content loss.
- WHERE a post is newly created by its author, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL allow self-editing for up to 15 minutes from initial publication.
- IF an edit is attempted after the self-edit window and the change is material, THEN THE civicDebateBoard SHALL route the edit for review and retain the original until a decision is made.
- WHILE a post is under pre-moderation due to policy or trust signals, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL keep the post non-public and display pending status to the author.
- WHEN a member follows a topic, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL include relevant new posts in the member’s personalized feed within 1 minute of publication.

### AMA Sessions (Verified Expertise)
- WHERE a session is tagged as "expert", THE civicDebateBoard SHALL restrict creation to verifiedMember and above.
- WHEN an AMA is scheduled, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL publish the session post at the scheduled time in the host’s configured timezone.
- WHEN questions are submitted to an active AMA, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL queue them for the host and reflect accepted questions to readers within 1 minute.
- IF an AMA session ends, THEN THE civicDebateBoard SHALL present a summary section and archive the session for read access.

### Reactions, Voting, and Anti-Manipulation
- WHERE an account is newly created or low-trust, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL apply stricter voting and reaction rate limits than for established members.
- WHEN a member casts a vote, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL reflect the vote effect in aggregates within 2 seconds.
- IF correlated voting patterns exceed manipulation thresholds, THEN THE civicDebateBoard SHALL dampen aggregated impact and flag the activity for moderator review.
- WHEN a member withdraws a vote within 10 minutes, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL reverse the aggregation accordingly.

### Reporting and Moderation
- WHEN a member submits a content report, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL acknowledge receipt instantly and assign a severity.
- WHERE a report is high severity (e.g., doxxing, threats), THE civicDebateBoard SHALL notify a moderator queue within 2 minutes.
- WHEN a moderator decides an outcome, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL notify the reporter and the author with the decision rationale within 1 minute of decision.
- IF a report is dismissed, THEN THE civicDebateBoard SHALL record the dismissal rationale in the audit log and mark the report resolved.
- WHEN a sanction is applied, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL enforce the sanction immediately across all user actions and persist its duration.
- WHERE a conflict-of-interest is detected for a reviewer, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL reassign the case and record the recusal with rationale.

### Fact-Checking and Annotations
- WHEN a factChecker adds an annotation with sources, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL display the annotation contextually on the referenced claim within 3 seconds to all readers.
- IF a factChecker proposes an enforcement-affecting label (e.g., reduced amplification), THEN THE civicDebateBoard SHALL require moderator confirmation before the label affects visibility.
- WHERE a conflict of interest is declared, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL route the annotation to an independent reviewer and pause enforcement changes until review completes.
- WHEN an author submits a correction addressing an accepted annotation, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL update the label to reflect the correction and display a transparency note.

### Appeals and Restorative Processes
- WHEN an author appeals a sanction within the allowed window, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL confirm receipt immediately and assign the appeal to a reviewer distinct from the original decision-maker.
- WHILE an appeal is pending, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL maintain the current enforcement unless policy specifies otherwise.
- WHEN an appeal is upheld, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL restore content visibility and notify affected parties within 1 minute.
- IF an appeal results in modified sanctions, THEN THE civicDebateBoard SHALL update enforcement and communicate changes with rationale.

### Notifications and Subscriptions (Instant and Digest)
- WHEN a followed thread receives a direct reply to the member’s content, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL send a notification within 1 minute.
- WHERE a member disables a notification category, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL cease notifications for that category within 1 minute.
- IF a notification cannot be delivered, THEN THE civicDebateBoard SHALL record a delivery failure and retry according to policy without duplicating user-visible messages.
- WHEN a member opts into daily digests for a category, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL include top items and deliver the digest according to the configured schedule.

### Account Lifecycle and Sessions
- WHEN a member revokes all sessions, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL terminate active sessions within 1 minute and require re-authentication.
- WHERE an account is suspended, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL restrict all posting, voting, and reporting actions for the suspension duration and label historical content per policy.
- IF a suspended account attempts a restricted action, THEN THE civicDebateBoard SHALL deny the action and display the remaining suspension duration.

### Accessibility, Inclusivity, and Localization
- THE civicDebateBoard SHALL present timestamps according to the user’s timezone preference with clear offset indicators.
- WHERE content includes sensitive topics, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL allow readers to access contextual safety and policy information within 2 clicks from the content.
- THE civicDebateBoard SHALL ensure that all user-facing messages are concise, unambiguous, and free of technical jargon.

### Transparency and Auditability
- WHEN any moderation or fact-check event occurs, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL record who initiated it, the reason category, the decision, and the time, in an immutable audit trail.
- IF a moderator is reassigned due to conflict of interest, THEN THE civicDebateBoard SHALL record the reassignment with rationale and timestamps.
- WHERE a role change is performed by an admin, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL notify the affected user and list the effective permissions change.
- WHEN an election window is activated, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL display an activation notice in transparency logs and apply elevated SLAs to relevant categories.

### Performance and Experience Expectations
- THE civicDebateBoard SHALL render user-triggered state changes (publish, vote, follow, report) as complete within 3 seconds in typical conditions.
- WHERE system load is elevated, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL continue to acknowledge user actions instantly and complete processing within published SLAs.
