# Non-Functional Requirements and SLAs — civicDebateBoard

## Performance Targets (response time by scenario)

Performance targets use percentile-based latency measured at the service boundary from user request receipt to first byte of server response. Targets exclude end-user network variability and device rendering but include all server-side processing and coordinated async acknowledgements documented as user-observable outcomes. Baseline, peak, and surge windows are defined to reflect civic-event dynamics.

### Core Read Scenarios
- Thread view (initial load of a discussion with first page of comments)
  - p95 ≤ 1.0 s; p99 ≤ 2.0 s
  - Subsequent page loads in same thread: p95 ≤ 0.8 s; p99 ≤ 1.5 s
- Topic/Category feed listing (first page)
  - p95 ≤ 1.0 s; p99 ≤ 2.0 s
  - Pagination/“next” fetches: p95 ≤ 0.7 s; p99 ≤ 1.4 s
- Notifications list fetch (latest 50 items)
  - p95 ≤ 0.8 s; p99 ≤ 1.5 s
- User profile read (public view)
  - p95 ≤ 0.7 s; p99 ≤ 1.2 s

### Write and Interaction Scenarios
- Create post (including server-side validations and topic/tag processing)
  - p95 ≤ 1.2 s; p99 ≤ 2.5 s
- Edit post within allowed policy window
  - p95 ≤ 1.0 s; p99 ≤ 2.0 s
- Create comment or reply
  - p95 ≤ 0.9 s; p99 ≤ 1.8 s
- Add reaction (like/support) or cast vote
  - p95 ≤ 0.5 s; p99 ≤ 1.0 s
  - Cross-device reflection (eventual consistency): visible to the same user’s other sessions within 2.0 s (p95) and 5.0 s (p99)
- Report content (submit report with category and notes)
  - p95 ≤ 0.8 s; p99 ≤ 1.5 s
- Fact-check annotation submission (by factChecker)
  - p95 ≤ 1.2 s; p99 ≤ 2.5 s

### Search and Discovery
- Simple search (keyword over titles/content, default filters)
  - p95 ≤ 1.5 s; p99 ≤ 3.0 s
- Advanced search (multiple filters such as date range, tags, author)
  - p95 ≤ 2.5 s; p99 ≤ 5.0 s
- Autocomplete suggestions (typeahead)
  - p95 ≤ 0.3 s; p99 ≤ 0.6 s

### Authentication and Account Management (business perspective)
- Login with valid credentials
  - p95 ≤ 2.0 s; p99 ≤ 4.0 s
- Email verification link consumption
  - p95 ≤ 1.0 s; p99 ≤ 2.0 s
- Password reset flow (token validation and new password set)
  - p95 ≤ 2.0 s; p99 ≤ 4.0 s

### Background and Asynchronous Outcomes (user-observable)
- Notification delivery for direct mentions and replies
  - p95 ≤ 10 s; p99 ≤ 30 s from event occurrence
- Moderation decision visibility after decision recorded
  - p95 ≤ 10 s; p99 ≤ 60 s to all relevant views
- Indexing latency for search after new content
  - p95 ≤ 30 s; p99 ≤ 120 s

### Concurrency and Throughput Assumptions (business-facing)
- Baseline steady state: 10,000 concurrent authenticated users, 2,000 read requests/s, 500 write requests/s
- Peak predictable events (e.g., election nights): up to 50,000 concurrent users, 10,000 read requests/s, 2,000 write requests/s
- Short surge (≤ 10 minutes) due to breaking news: up to 2× peak for reads and 1.5× peak for writes
- Targets SHALL hold under baseline; during peak/surge windows, p95 and p99 targets may degrade by at most +30% latency while maintaining availability objectives

### Cold-Start and Cache Warm-Up Behavior
- First access after cache cold start for any high-volume listing (topic feed, home feed) may incur up to +20% additional latency at p95 for ≤ 5 minutes after deployment or failover; p99 must remain within +30% of baseline.
- Warm cache steady-state must regain baseline targets within 5 minutes of stabilization.

### Payload and Pagination Consistency Expectations
- Result pages for feeds and search SHALL contain 20 items by default with stable sorting and no duplicates across contiguous pages under the same query parameters.
- Aggregated counters (reactions, votes) may be eventually consistent across sessions but MUST converge within 5 seconds at p99 for the acting user’s view.

## Availability and Reliability Objectives

Availability targets are measured monthly unless specified. Availability is the proportion of successful user operations over total attempted operations for the capability, excluding client-originated failures outside the service boundary and scheduled maintenance within the announced window.

### Service-Level Objectives (SLOs)
- Core read operations (view thread, list feeds): 99.95% monthly availability
- Core write operations (create/edit posts/comments, vote/reaction): 99.90% monthly availability
- Authentication and session operations: 99.90% monthly availability
- Search services: 99.90% monthly availability

### Error Budgets and Release Governance
- 99.95% monthly leaves 21.6 minutes unavailability budget; 99.90% leaves 43.8 minutes.
- At 50% budget consumption: restrict non-critical changes and require explicit approval for risk-elevating deployments.
- At 100% consumption: freeze non-emergency changes until budget resets.

#### Change Freeze Trigger Flow
```mermaid
graph LR
  A["Track Error Budget Consumption"] --> B{"Reached 50%?"}
  B -->|"Yes"| C["Restrict Non-Critical Changes"]
  B -->|"No"| D["Continue Normal Changes"]
  C --> E{"Reached 100%?"}
  D --> E
  E -->|"Yes"| F["Freeze Non-Emergency Changes"]
  E -->|"No"| G["Monitor & Reassess Daily"]
```

### Maintenance Windows
- Planned maintenance up to 60 minutes per month, scheduled at low-traffic times and announced at least 72 hours in advance with local-time communication for impacted regions.
- Prefer degraded-mode maintenance (read-only) over full downtime with clear user notices.

### Graceful Degradation Expectations
- Prioritize read availability over non-critical write operations and background tasks during impairments.
- Temporarily disable heavy, non-essential features (e.g., bulk data exports) to protect core SLOs.

### SLA Measurement and Reporting
- Measurement window: monthly calendar period with daily rollups.
- Inclusion criteria: successful operations are those completed within published latency and functional correctness; degraded but retried within the same interaction counts as success if within user-visible SLA.
- Exclusions: client-side network errors, third-party outages beyond control with documented supplier incident references, and scheduled maintenance communicated ≥ 72 hours in advance.
- Reporting: publish monthly availability summaries per capability with error budget status and top contributing incidents.

### User-Facing Status Communications
- Incident status pages and in-product banners must reflect current impact, affected capabilities, start time, and next update ETA.
- Update cadence: every 30 minutes for active major incidents; every 60 minutes for minor incidents until resolved.

## Capacity and Scalability Goals

- Planning horizon: 12 months rolling with quarterly review.
- Headroom policy: maintain ≥ 30% spare capacity over the 95th percentile observed demand; ≥ 50% during known high-impact civic events.
- Elasticity: scale-out actions commence within 2 minutes of sustained (≥ 5 minutes) demand beyond headroom; scale-in after 30 minutes of sub-70% utilization to avoid thrashing.
- Data growth assumptions: 1–2 million new posts/month, 10–20 million new comments/month; proportional growth in reactions and votes.
- Multi-tenant fairness: per-topic or per-region spikes must not starve other topics/regions; apply isolation and quotas to protect fairness.

### Data Consistency and Backlog Management
- Async backlogs (notifications, indexing) must drain to within normal operating thresholds within 15 minutes after surge subsides.
- Search indexing lag must meet p95 ≤ 30 s; p99 ≤ 120 s under steady-state and return to targets within 10 minutes post-surge.

## Rate Limiting and Fair-Use Policies

Rate limits protect platform health and fairness. Limits are enforced per authenticated user and, where applicable, per-IP to mitigate abuse. Role-specific limits reflect trust and responsibility. Administrative and moderation functions necessary for safety are exempt from general content-creation caps but remain subject to platform protection.

### Action-Based Daily Quotas by Role

| Action (per 24h rolling window) | member | verifiedMember | factChecker | moderator | admin |
|---------------------------------|--------|----------------|-------------|-----------|-------|
| Create posts                    | 30     | 60             | 60          | 120       | 240   |
| Comments/replies                | 300    | 600            | 600         | 1,200     | 2,400 |
| Reactions (likes/support)       | 3,000  | 5,000          | 5,000       | 10,000    | 20,000|
| Votes (polls/ballots)           | 1,000  | 2,000          | 2,000       | 5,000     | 10,000|
| Reports submitted               | 100    | 200            | 300         | 5,000     | 5,000 |
| Fact-check annotations          | —      | —              | 100         | 300       | 300   |
| Data exports (on-demand)        | 2      | 2              | 4           | 10        | 20    |

Notes:
- “—” denotes action not available to that role.
- High-volume administrative operations affecting many items may require additional confirmations and audit entries per safety and compliance policies.

### Per-User and Per-IP Request Shaping
- Sustained per-user request rate: 60 requests/minute with burst up to 3× for 10 seconds; cooldown applies if exceeded.
- Per-IP guideline: 120 requests/minute with burst up to 3× for 10 seconds; stricter thresholds may apply for shared networks with abusive patterns.
- Search-specific limit per minute/hour: 20/100 (member), 40/200 (verifiedMember), 60/300 (factChecker), 120/600 (moderator/admin).

### Abuse Response and Recovery
- Progressive throttling: soft warnings → temporary slowdowns → temporary blocks within the same 24h window; resets after the rolling window elapses.
- Human verification may be required when automated abuse signals exceed thresholds.
- Accuracy-weighted reporting: frequent inaccurate reporters may see reduced report quotas until accuracy improves per moderation policies.

## Observability Expectations (business terms)

Observability enables rapid detection, triage, and resolution of issues to protect user experience and SLAs. Expectations are stated as outcomes and signal categories, not tooling.

### Business Event Logging
- Authentication events: registration, login success/failure, logout, email verification, password reset, device/session revocation.
- Content lifecycle: post/comment creation, edits, deletions, restores, visibility changes (e.g., moderation actions), tagging/topic updates.
- User safety: reports, triage outcomes, sanctions applied, appeals and outcomes.
- Configuration and policy changes: role assignments, feature toggles, category/tag configuration, sanctions configuration.
- Elevated data access: exports and policy audits.

Logs include sufficient context to trace who acted, what changed, and when, with privacy compliance consistent with security and compliance requirements.

### Metrics and Health Indicators
- Latency distributions: p50/p95/p99 for key flows defined in Performance Targets.
- Availability: success rate per capability excluding client/network errors.
- Saturation: high-level indicators (queue depth, worker utilization) of constrained capacity.
- Workload: request rates, concurrency, job backlogs.
- Operability KPIs: report backlog age, moderation decision latency, notification delivery latency.

### Alerting and Operational Response
- Thresholds mapped to SLOs and user impact:
  - Critical: page immediately when projected to breach SLO within 30 minutes or user-visible errors exceed 2% for 5 minutes.
  - High: page when p99 latency exceeds target by 50% for 10 minutes under baseline.
  - Moderate: ticket for chronic degradations without immediate user impact.
- On-call availability: 24/7 coverage with acknowledgement within 5 minutes (critical) and 15 minutes (high); mitigation or rollback initiated within 15 minutes (critical) and 30 minutes (high).
- Post-incident review: completed within 5 business days with action items tracked to completion.

#### Incident Alerting and Escalation Flow
```mermaid
sequenceDiagram
  participant U as "User Experience"
  participant M as "Metrics/Alerts"
  participant OC as "On-Call Engineer"
  participant IM as "Incident Manager"
  participant ST as "Service Team"
  U->>M: "User-visible degradation detected"
  M-->>OC: "Page (critical/high)"
  OC->>U: "Mitigation actions(traffic shaping, feature gating)"
  OC->>IM: "Declare incident and severity"
  IM->>ST: "Coordinate response and updates"
  ST->>U: "Restore service and confirm SLO compliance"
```

### Change Management and Release Governance
- Release windows: prefer low-traffic times aligned to major user regions; avoid scheduled releases during published election windows.
- Canary/gradual rollout expectations: progressive exposure with rollback criteria tied to SLO deltas and error budget consumption.
- Rollback targets: decision within 15 minutes of critical alert if regression persists.

## Backup and Disaster Recovery Objectives (RTO/RPO)

- Backup coverage: user-generated content, policy configurations, and audit records required for legal and operational accountability.
- Backup frequency: at least every 15 minutes for critical transactional data; daily immutable snapshots for full datasets.
- Retention: minimum 30 days online; 180 days in archive for compliance-relevant records, subject to privacy obligations.
- Recovery Point Objective (RPO): ≤ 15 minutes for critical data; ≤ 60 minutes for non-critical indexes and caches.
- Recovery Time Objective (RTO): ≤ 60 minutes for single-region outages affecting core operations; ≤ 4 hours for full regional failover.
- Restore testing: quarterly restore drills for critical datasets with evidence of success and measured RTO/RPO compliance.

#### Disaster Recovery Decision Flow
```mermaid
graph LR
  A["Degradation or Outage Detected"] --> B{"Within Error Budget?"}
  B -->|"Yes"| C["Mitigate and Monitor"]
  B -->|"No"| D["Initiate Failover Runbook"]
  C --> E{"Resolved < 30 min?"}
  E -->|"Yes"| F["Close Incident"]
  E -->|"No"| D
  D --> G["Restore Data to RPO Targets"]
  G --> H["Validate Core Capabilities"]
  H --> I{"Meets RTO?"}
  I -->|"Yes"| F
  I -->|"No"| J["Escalate and Communicate Extended ETA"]
```

## Internationalization and Timezone Considerations

- Timestamps are displayed in the user’s configured timezone and locale formats, with an option to view in UTC.
- Relative time phrasing is acceptable when unambiguous and accompanied by absolute time upon request.
- Daylight saving and regional calendar differences are respected for date ranges and limits.
- Rolling windows for rate limits are anchored to UTC for fairness and predictability; user interfaces communicate remaining quotas in the user’s timezone.
- Notifications and scheduled communications respect the recipient’s local quiet hours where configured.
- Regional incident communications are localized to impacted regions’ local time with clear conversion to UTC for audit.

# civicDebateBoard Security, Privacy, and Compliance Requirements

This document defines the business requirements for security, privacy, and compliance for the civicDebateBoard service. It specifies WHAT the system must do from a compliance and safety perspective in clear, testable terms, without prescribing HOW to implement it. All technical implementation decisions (architecture, APIs, database design, cryptographic choices, tooling) are at the discretion of the development team.

## Introduction and Scope
civicDebateBoard facilitates civic discourse with roles [member, verifiedMember, factChecker, moderator, admin]. This document governs how user data is handled, how access is controlled, how activities are audited, and how incidents are managed to meet legal and ethical obligations across jurisdictions in which the service operates. Requirements herein are expressed in business terms and must be treated as mandatory acceptance criteria.

- In-Scope: Data privacy obligations, consent management, user rights, business-level security expectations, audit logging, incident response, regulatory conformance, third-party risk.
- Out-of-Scope: UI/UX specifications, API endpoints, database schemas, cryptographic algorithms, network or infrastructure choices.

For role definitions and session behaviors, see the User Roles and Authentication Requirements in [User Roles and Authentication Requirements](./03-user-roles-and-authentication.md). For performance, availability, and disaster recovery expectations, see [Non-Functional Requirements and SLAs](./08-non-functional-requirements-and-slas.md).

## Data Privacy Principles and Consent Management
civicDebateBoard adheres to the following privacy principles: purpose limitation, data minimization, transparency, integrity and confidentiality, storage limitation, and accountability. Consent is one lawful basis among others (e.g., contract, legitimate interest) and must be handled explicitly when required.

### Data Categories and Classification (Business View)
| Category | Examples | Sensitivity | Default Collection | Default Sharing |
|---------|----------|-------------|--------------------|-----------------|
| Account Data | email, display name, role, verification status | Personal | Required for account | Not shared externally |
| Content Data | posts, comments, reactions, bookmarks | Varies (may include personal) | Optional per user action | Public if posted publicly |
| Behavioral Data | follows, subscriptions, notification preferences, rate-limit counters | Personal | Limited to service operation | Not shared externally |
| Security Data | login events, device sessions, password reset requests, sanctions | Personal | Required for security | Not shared externally |
| Moderation Data | reports, review decisions, sanctions, appeals | Personal | Required for policy enforcement | Not shared externally |
| Analytics Data | aggregated usage metrics | Aggregated/De-identified | Optional per consent where required | Shared only in aggregate |

### Privacy Disclosures and Consent
- Transparency: Users must receive clear disclosures about purposes of processing, categories of data collected, retention periods, and sharing practices at or before the point of collection.
- Consent: Explicit consent must be obtained before processing categories that require consent by law (e.g., certain analytics, marketing communications, location-based personalization where applicable). Consent must be granular, freely given, informed, unambiguous, and revocable at any time without detriment.
- Legitimate Interest: Where legitimate interest is used as a lawful basis, a documented balancing test must be maintained and users must be offered an easy opt-out when required.

### Cookie/Identifier Preferences and "Do Not Sell/Share"
- Cookie and identifier preferences must be honored, including Global Privacy Control (GPC) or similar browser-level signals where applicable.
- Marketing communications and cross-context behavioral advertising must be opt-in where required and opt-out at minimum elsewhere; non-discrimination rules apply.

### EARS Requirements — Privacy and Consent
- THE civicDebateBoard SHALL present purpose-specific privacy disclosures prior to any data collection that is not strictly necessary for core service operation.
- THE civicDebateBoard SHALL record the timestamp, scope, and version of the disclosure accepted by the user for any consent-based processing.
- WHEN a user withdraws consent for a processing purpose, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL cease that processing within 24 hours and ensure no new data is collected for that purpose thereafter.
- WHEN consent is required for analytics beyond strictly necessary operations, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL default to opt-out and SHALL enable opt-in only after explicit user action.
- IF a processing purpose changes materially, THEN THE civicDebateBoard SHALL obtain fresh consent before continuing consent-based processing under the new purpose.
- WHERE legal bases other than consent are relied upon, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL expose a clear explanation of the applicable legal basis within the privacy notice.
- WHERE a GPC or equivalent signal is received, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL treat it as a valid opt-out of sale/share for applicable jurisdictions and SHALL persist that preference.

### Consent Lifecycle (Business Flow)
```mermaid
graph LR
  A["Collect Purpose-Specific Disclosure"] --> B["Capture Consent State(Opt-in/Opt-out)"]
  B --> C{"Consent Required?"}
  C -->|"Yes"| D["Enforce Purpose Access Controls"]
  C -->|"No"| E["Proceed Under Other Legal Basis"]
  D --> F{"Withdrawal Requested?"}
  F -->|"Yes"| G["Stop Processing(<24h) & Log Withdrawal"]
  F -->|"No"| H["Continue Processing"]
  E --> H
```

## User Rights (Access, Correction, Deletion)
User rights procedures must ensure timely, secure, and verifiable fulfillment of requests.

### Identity Verification for Requests
- Requests to access, correct, or delete data must be verified using reasonable methods proportionate to the sensitivity of the data and the risk of harm from unauthorized access. The verification method must not require excessive data.

### DSAR Intake and Fulfillment Timelines
- GDPR: Respond to access, correction, and deletion requests without undue delay and within 30 calendar days of receipt; a single extension up to 60 additional days is allowed when justified by complexity, with notification to the requester within the original 30 days.
- CCPA/CPRA: Respond to access and deletion requests within 45 days; a 45-day extension is allowed when reasonably necessary with notice to the consumer.

### Packaging of Responses
- Access responses must include a human-readable summary and a machine-readable portable format commonly used in the industry, limited to the requestor’s personal data and clearly excluding other users’ data.

### Deletion Scope and Exceptions
- Deletion removes personal data that is not required for legal, security, or integrity obligations. Content removals may leave a publicly visible tombstone where necessary to preserve discussion coherence without revealing personal data.

### Portability, Restriction, and Opt-Outs
- Portability: Provide a structured, commonly used, machine-readable export of personal data the user provided and, where applicable, data observed through their use of the service.
- Restriction: Temporarily limit processing where legally required while preserving data integrity for the restriction period.
- Opt-Outs: Honor user opt-outs of sale/share, targeted advertising, and profiling where required by law without degrading core functionality.

### Non-Discrimination
- Users exercising rights shall not be charged different prices or receive a different level or quality of goods or services unless permitted by law and disclosed.

### Retention and Storage Limitation
| Data Type | Default Retention | Extensions and Holds | Final Disposition |
|----------|-------------------|----------------------|-------------------|
| Account Data | Lifetime of account + 30 days after deletion | Extended for legal holds | Permanent deletion |
| Content Data | Lifetime of content; user-initiated deletion immediate | Retained in backups per backup window | Removal from active service; anonymized references where necessary |
| Security Logs | 12 months | Extended for investigations/legal holds | Secure deletion |
| Moderation Records | 24 months | Extended through appeal window and legal holds | Secure deletion or anonymization |
| Incident Records | 5 years | As required by regulation | Secure deletion |
| Backups | Up to 30 days | No extension absent legal holds | Rolling overwrite |

### EARS Requirements — User Rights
- WHEN a user submits a verified access request, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL provide a complete copy of the user’s personal data within the applicable legal timeframe and SHALL log the fulfillment event for audit.
- WHEN a user submits a verified correction request, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL update inaccurate personal data within 30 days and SHALL notify the user upon completion.
- WHEN a user submits a verified deletion request, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL delete personal data not required for legal or security obligations within 30 days and SHALL document exceptions with reasons.
- IF identity verification for a rights request fails, THEN THE civicDebateBoard SHALL reject the request and SHALL provide a reason and a path to re-verify without revealing sensitive information.
- WHERE the law permits timeline extensions, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL notify the requester of the extension and the justification before the original deadline expires.
- WHILE a legal hold is active, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL suspend deletion for data subject to the hold and SHALL resume deletion once the hold is lifted.
- WHEN a portability request is verified, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL provide a structured, commonly used, machine-readable export within legal timelines.
- WHEN a restriction request is verified, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL mark affected data as restricted and SHALL prevent processing except for storage and legal obligations for the restriction duration.
- WHEN a user opts out of targeted advertising or sale/share, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL cease such processing within 15 days and SHALL confirm the opt-out state to the user.

### DSAR Lifecycle (Business Flow)
```mermaid
graph LR
  A["Receive DSAR(Request Type)"] --> B["Verify Identity(Reasonable Method)"]
  B --> C{"Verified?"}
  C -->|"No"| D["Deny & Provide Re-verify Path"]
  C -->|"Yes"| E["Locate Data & Assess Scope"]
  E --> F{"Extension Needed?"}
  F -->|"Yes"| G["Notify Extension & Justification"]
  F -->|"No"| H["Prepare Response(Package Type)"]
  G --> H
  H --> I["Deliver Response & Log Audit"]
```

## Security Expectations (Access Control, Data Protection in Business Terms)
Security requirements are expressed as business obligations that protect users and the integrity of discourse while respecting role-based access.

### Role-Based Access Expectations
| Data/Action | member | verifiedMember | factChecker | moderator | admin |
|------------|--------|----------------|------------|----------|-------|
| View own Account Data | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ |
| Edit own Account Data | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ |
| View other users’ Account Data | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | Limited to enforcement need | Limited to administrative need |
| Access Content Data (public) | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ |
| Access flagged Moderation Data | ❌ | ❌ | Propose annotations only | ✅ | ✅ |
| Issue sanctions | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ✅ | ✅ |
| Manage roles and platform policies | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ✅ |

Note: Detailed role semantics are defined in [User Roles and Authentication Requirements](./03-user-roles-and-authentication.md). This table expresses high-level business permissions only.

### Protection of Data in Transit and at Rest (Business Level)
- Communications and stored data containing personal information must be protected against unauthorized access. Protection mechanisms must align with industry standards and regulatory expectations without specifying exact technologies here.

### Secrets and Key Material Handling (Business Level)
- Secrets must be treated as confidential assets, access must be strictly limited to those with a business need, and rotation must occur on a regular cadence and upon suspected exposure.

### Account and Session Protections (Business Level)
- Authentication, session duration, revocation, and device management are governed by [User Roles and Authentication Requirements](./03-user-roles-and-authentication.md). This document requires outcomes: resistant to brute-force attempts, rapid revocation on logout-all events, and safe handling of password resets and email verification.

### Workforce Training and Access Reviews
- Personnel with access to personal data must complete annual privacy and security training with role-appropriate modules.
- Access to systems containing personal data must be reviewed at least quarterly and upon role changes.

### Vulnerability Disclosure and Security Testing (Business Level)
- A public channel for responsible vulnerability disclosure must exist with commitments to timely triage and remediation.
- Periodic security testing (e.g., third-party assessments) must be conducted on a risk-based cadence without prescribing tools.

### EARS Requirements — Security Expectations
- THE civicDebateBoard SHALL enforce least-privilege access aligned with user roles for all data categories listed in this document.
- WHEN a user’s role changes, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL apply the new permissions immediately and SHALL invalidate any access inconsistent with the new role.
- WHEN a user logs out of all devices, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL ensure that no previously issued session remains valid beyond 60 seconds after the action.
- IF repeated failed authentication attempts indicate brute-force behavior, THEN THE civicDebateBoard SHALL temporarily block further attempts from the source and SHALL preserve relevant Security Data for investigation.
- WHERE personal data is stored, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL ensure that unauthorized access is prevented using industry-standard protection mechanisms both in transit and at rest.
- WHEN secrets exposure is suspected, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL rotate affected secrets within 24 hours and SHALL invalidate dependent credentials promptly.
- THE civicDebateBoard SHALL require annual privacy and security training for personnel with access to personal data and SHALL record completion.
- THE civicDebateBoard SHALL conduct quarterly access reviews for privileged roles and SHALL remove access that is no longer required.
- WHEN a vulnerability report is received through the responsible disclosure channel, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL acknowledge receipt within 7 days and SHALL provide status updates until resolution.

## Audit Logging and Accountability Requirements
Auditability ensures traceability of significant actions while respecting privacy.

### Scope of Auditable Events (Business View)
- Authentication lifecycle events (registration, login, logout, password reset, email verification)
- Role and permission changes
- Content lifecycle events (create, edit, delete, restore)
- Moderation lifecycle events (report intake, triage, decision, sanction, appeal, reinstatement)
- Privacy events (consent grant/withdrawal, DSAR intake/fulfillment)
- Security events (failed logins spikes, admin access, configuration changes)

### Required Audit Record Elements (Semantic Fields)
- Actor identity and role at time of action
- Action type and target object category
- Timestamp in a standardized, consistent time basis
- Outcome (success/denied/error) and reason code if denied
- High-level origin context (e.g., device type or general location as permitted by law)
- Correlation identifier for multi-step processes

### Access and Integrity of Audit Logs
- Access to audit logs must be restricted to admin and authorized moderator functions used for investigations.
- Logs must be tamper-evident and retained per schedule without exposing personal data beyond necessity.

### EARS Requirements — Audit and Accountability
- THE civicDebateBoard SHALL record audit entries for all events listed in the Scope of Auditable Events.
- WHEN an auditable event is recorded, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL include actor identity, role, action type, target category, timestamp, outcome, and correlation identifier.
- WHERE an action is denied due to insufficient permissions, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL record the denial reason without exposing sensitive data.
- IF audit log access is requested by an unauthorized role, THEN THE civicDebateBoard SHALL deny access and SHALL record the attempt.
- WHILE an investigation is active, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL protect relevant logs from alteration or deletion and SHALL lift protection once the investigation concludes.

## Incident Response and Breach Notification
Incident management ensures rapid detection, containment, and communication proportionate to severity.

### Severity Levels and SLAs
| Severity | Description | Initial Triage | Containment | User/Authority Notification |
|---------|-------------|----------------|-------------|-----------------------------|
| Sev 1 | Confirmed breach of personal data with high risk | Within 1 hour | Within 4 hours | Authorities within 72 hours where required; affected users without undue delay and within 7 days |
| Sev 2 | Suspected breach or material service abuse | Within 4 hours | Within 24 hours | Notify affected users if risk is nontrivial; authority notification per law |
| Sev 3 | Security weakness or limited exposure with low risk | Within 1 business day | Within 3 business days | No notification unless legally required |

### Incident Lifecycle (Business Flow)
```mermaid
graph LR
  A["Detect Event"] --> B{"Severity Assessed"}
  B -->|"Sev 1"| C["Containment Actions"]
  B -->|"Sev 2/3"| C
  C --> D["Forensics & Impact Determination"]
  D --> E{"Personal Data Involved?"}
  E -->|"Yes"| F["Regulatory Notification Prep"]
  E -->|"No"| G["Remediation Plan"]
  F --> H["Notify Authorities"]
  F --> I["Notify Affected Users"]
  G --> J["Execute Remediation"]
  H --> K["Postmortem & Lessons"]
  I --> K
  J --> K
```

### Breach Notification Content (Business Expectations)
- Nature of the incident, categories and approximate number of data subjects and records involved (where known), likely consequences, measures taken or proposed to address the breach, and guidance for affected users to mitigate harm.

### EARS Requirements — Incident Response
- WHEN a potential incident is detected, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL initiate severity assessment within the timeframes specified in the Severity Levels and SLAs table.
- WHEN an incident reaches Sev 1, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL complete initial containment within 4 hours and SHALL prepare regulatory notifications as required.
- IF personal data is likely exposed, THEN THE civicDebateBoard SHALL notify authorities within 72 hours where applicable and SHALL notify affected users without undue delay using clear guidance on protective steps.
- WHERE a legal hold is established as part of an incident, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL suspend routine deletions of affected data until the hold is lifted.
- THE civicDebateBoard SHALL conduct a post-incident review within 10 business days of containment, including root cause, impact, and remediation actions.

## Regulatory Compliance (GDPR, CCPA, Election-Related Policies)
The service must operate in compliance with applicable privacy laws and content-related obligations where it is offered.

### Lawful Bases and Transparency
- Identify and document lawful bases per processing purpose (e.g., contract for account operation; legitimate interest for safety; consent for marketing where applicable). Privacy notices must reflect these bases in clear language.

### Cross-Border Data Transfers
- Where personal data is transferred across borders, use valid transfer mechanisms recognized by the destination and origin jurisdictions and maintain records of such transfers and safeguards.

### DPIA and Records of Processing
- Conduct Data Protection Impact Assessments (DPIAs) for high-risk processing and maintain Records of Processing Activities (RoPA) at a level sufficient for regulatory inspection.

### Minors and Age-Gating
- The service is designed for civic discourse and may be restricted for minors based on jurisdictional requirements. Where participation by minors is permitted, verifiable parental consent must be in place if required by local law.

### Election-Related Integrity and Transparency
- For features involving political content classifications or labels, ensure transparency notices and access to corrective pathways (e.g., appeals, fact-check annotations) consistent with policy documents and applicable regulations.

### EARS Requirements — Regulatory Compliance
- THE civicDebateBoard SHALL maintain a privacy notice that lists processing purposes, lawful bases, categories of data, retention periods, and data sharing practices.
- WHERE cross-border transfers occur, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL document the transfer mechanism and SHALL make a summary available upon request.
- WHEN operating in jurisdictions requiring age-gating, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL restrict access by minors unless verifiable consent requirements are satisfied.
- WHEN processing political or election-related content categories, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL present transparency labels and SHALL preserve a record of labeling and review actions.
- WHERE processing presents high risk to individuals, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL conduct a DPIA before launch and SHALL document mitigations and residual risk.
- THE civicDebateBoard SHALL maintain Records of Processing Activities sufficient to describe purposes, categories, recipients, transfers, and retention for each processing activity.

## Third-Party and Integration Risk Management
Third parties include analytics providers, email delivery services, identity verification services, and content safety partners. The service remains accountable for data shared with subprocessors.

### Third-Party Onboarding and Oversight
- Due diligence must evaluate data protection posture, contractual commitments, breach history, and data locality. Data processing agreements must be in place when personal data is processed on behalf of civicDebateBoard.

### Data Sharing Minimization and Controls
- Share only the minimum personal data necessary for the stated purpose. Prohibit third parties from selling, reusing, or combining personal data for unrelated purposes.

### Subprocessor Registry and Notifications
- Maintain a public-facing list of subprocessors that handle personal data and provide advance notice of material changes where legally required.

### Reassessment Cadence and Termination
- Reassess critical subprocessors at least annually and upon material change; ensure secure data return or deletion upon termination.

### EARS Requirements — Third-Party Risk
- WHEN engaging a new third party that processes personal data, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL execute a data processing agreement and SHALL document a due diligence assessment prior to activation.
- WHERE a third party is no longer necessary, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL terminate data flows and SHALL ensure data return or deletion as contractually required within 30 days.
- IF a third party reports a breach impacting civicDebateBoard data, THEN THE civicDebateBoard SHALL trigger the incident response process and SHALL assess notification obligations.
- THE civicDebateBoard SHALL maintain and publish a current subprocessor list that includes categories of services and data types processed.
- THE civicDebateBoard SHALL reassess critical subprocessors at least annually and SHALL record reassessment outcomes and follow-ups.

## Governance and Privacy-by-Design
Governance embeds privacy and security into the lifecycle of features and operations.

### Privacy-by-Design Checkpoints
- Kickoff: Define purposes, lawful bases, data minimization strategies, and retention for new features.
- Pre-Launch: Complete DPIA where required, finalize disclosures and consent flows, confirm role-based access, validate audit events.
- Post-Launch: Monitor KPIs and incidents, review data retention alignment, and adjust controls as needed.

### Training and Awareness
- Annual training for all staff; enhanced training for moderators, admins, and engineers who handle personal data.

### Access Governance
- Joiner-Mover-Leaver process to ensure timely provisioning and deprovisioning of access based on role changes.

### De-Identification and Re-Identification Prohibition
- De-identified data must be managed to prevent re-identification, and any attempt to re-identify de-identified data is prohibited.

### EARS Requirements — Governance
- THE civicDebateBoard SHALL require privacy-by-design reviews at kickoff, pre-launch, and post-launch for features involving personal data.
- WHEN a high-risk feature is proposed, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL mandate a DPIA and SHALL approve mitigations before launch.
- THE civicDebateBoard SHALL require annual privacy training for all staff and enhanced training for roles with elevated data access.
- WHEN an employee changes roles or leaves, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL adjust or revoke access within 24 hours and SHALL log the change.
- THE civicDebateBoard SHALL prohibit re-identification of de-identified data and SHALL treat any detected attempt as a policy violation subject to sanction.

## EARS-Formatted Compliance Requirements (Consolidated)
This section consolidates key testable requirements for verification. All descriptions use business language and keep EARS keywords in English.

### Privacy and Consent
- THE civicDebateBoard SHALL display purpose-specific privacy disclosures before any optional data collection.
- WHEN consent is withdrawn, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL stop consent-based processing within 24 hours and SHALL record the withdrawal.
- IF processing purposes change, THEN THE civicDebateBoard SHALL obtain renewed consent where consent is the legal basis.
- WHERE a GPC signal is received, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL honor it as an opt-out of sale/share in applicable jurisdictions.

### User Rights
- WHEN a verified access request is received, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL fulfill it within legal timelines and SHALL log the fulfillment.
- WHEN a verified deletion request is received, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL delete eligible data within 30 days and SHALL document exceptions.
- IF verification fails for a rights request, THEN THE civicDebateBoard SHALL deny the request with a non-sensitive reason.
- WHEN a portability request is verified, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL provide a structured export within legal timelines.
- WHEN a restriction request is verified, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL prevent processing for the restriction duration except storage and legal obligations.
- WHEN a user opts out of targeted advertising or sale/share, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL cease such processing within 15 days.

### Security and Access Control
- THE civicDebateBoard SHALL enforce least-privilege access for all roles and data categories.
- WHEN a role changes, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL apply the new permissions immediately and SHALL invalidate inconsistent sessions.
- IF brute-force indicators are detected, THEN THE civicDebateBoard SHALL throttle attempts and SHALL retain evidence for 12 months.
- THE civicDebateBoard SHALL require annual training for personnel with access to personal data and SHALL record completion.
- THE civicDebateBoard SHALL conduct quarterly privileged-access reviews and SHALL remove unnecessary access.

### Audit and Accountability
- THE civicDebateBoard SHALL record audit events with actor, role, action type, target category, timestamp, outcome, and correlation identifier.
- IF unauthorized access to audit logs is attempted, THEN THE civicDebateBoard SHALL deny it and SHALL record the attempt.
- WHILE an investigation is active, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL protect relevant logs from alteration or deletion.

### Incident Response
- WHEN an incident is detected, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL assess severity within defined SLAs and SHALL contain confirmed Sev 1 incidents within 4 hours.
- IF personal data is exposed, THEN THE civicDebateBoard SHALL notify authorities within 72 hours where required and SHALL notify affected users without undue delay.
- THE civicDebateBoard SHALL complete a post-incident review within 10 business days of containment.

### Regulatory and Third-Party
- WHERE data crosses borders, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL document transfer mechanisms and SHALL provide summaries upon request.
- WHEN onboarding a personal-data processor, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL execute a data processing agreement and SHALL document due diligence.
- IF a subprocessor incident impacts civicDebateBoard data, THEN THE civicDebateBoard SHALL activate incident response and SHALL evaluate notification duties.
- THE civicDebateBoard SHALL reassess critical subprocessors at least annually and SHALL record outcomes.
- WHERE processing is high-risk, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL conduct a DPIA before launch and SHALL document mitigations.

## Appendices

### Appendix A — Glossary (Business Terms)
- Personal Data: Information relating to an identified or identifiable individual.
- Consent: Freely given, specific, informed, and unambiguous indication of wishes by which the data subject signifies agreement to processing.
- DSAR: Data Subject Access Request; includes access, correction, deletion, portability where applicable.
- Legal Hold: A process that suspends routine deletion due to litigation, investigations, or regulatory obligations.
- Subprocessor: A third party engaged to process personal data on behalf of the service.
- GPC: Global Privacy Control; a browser-level signal indicating user opt-out of sale/share of personal data where applicable.
- DPIA: Data Protection Impact Assessment; process to evaluate high-risk processing.
- RoPA: Records of Processing Activities; a register of processing purposes, categories, and other required details.

### Appendix B — Data Categories (Detailed Examples)

- Content Data: posts, comments, reactions, bookmarks, follows, topics.
- Security Data: login attempts, session metadata, password reset events, device revocations.
- Moderation Data: reports, review decisions, sanctions, appeals, reinstatement status.
- Analytics Data: aggregated usage metrics and de-identified trend summaries subject to consent where required.

### Appendix C — Severity Matrix (Quick Reference)

| Sev 2 | Medium risk or uncertain breach | Conditional per risk and law |
| Sev 3 | Low risk or contained weakness | None unless required |

# civicDebateBoard — Business Model and Analytics

Business requirements only; all technical implementation decisions (architecture, APIs, data pipelines, analytics tooling, storage, dashboards) remain at the discretion of the development team. Describes WHAT outcomes must be achieved in business terms, not HOW to implement them.

## 1) Why This Service Exists (recap)

civicDebateBoard improves the quality, transparency, and civility of online civic discourse. Structured discussions, fact-checking roles, and policy-aligned moderation workflows enable responsible debate on complex topics.

Differentiators
- Role design that includes verifiedMember and factChecker to elevate credibility and timely corrections.
- Measurable safety and transparency requirements that prioritize community health over raw engagement.
- Governance for data use and analytics that protects privacy and democratic processes.

Alignment with related documents
- Strategic vision and scope: [Service Vision and Overview](./01-service-vision-and-overview.md).
- Capabilities and constraints for user actions: [Functional Requirements](./06-functional-requirements.md).
- Performance and availability expectations: [Non-Functional Requirements and SLAs](./08-non-functional-requirements-and-slas.md).

## 2) Revenue Strategy Options and Guardrails

Sustainable monetization must never compromise civic integrity or user trust. Approaches may be combined under strict guardrails.

### 2.1 Advertising (Contextual, Non-Microtargeted)
- Contextual placements adjacent to topics; never embedded within arguments to avoid misattribution.
- No behavioral microtargeting based on sensitive attributes or political beliefs.
- Frequency caps and clear, persistent disclosures for paid placements.

EARS Requirements — Advertising
- THE civicDebateBoard SHALL label paid placements with an unambiguous disclosure visible wherever the placement appears.
- WHERE advertising is enabled, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL apply a per-user daily impression cap of 3 impressions per unique campaign.
- WHERE advertising is enabled, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL prohibit targeting based on sensitive attributes including political affiliation, religion, health status, or inferred beliefs.
- IF a paid placement conflicts with safety policies (misinformation, hate speech, election manipulation), THEN THE civicDebateBoard SHALL reject the placement and provide a categorical reason to the advertiser.
- WHEN a user opts out of personalized ads, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL restrict ad selection to contextual signals and record the consent state for compliance reporting.
- WHILE a political event moratorium (election blackout) is active, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL disable new political ad activations and freeze existing political campaigns.
- WHERE an ad appears near user-generated content, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL ensure adjacency rules avoid implying endorsement by the adjacent author.

### 2.2 Sponsorships (Topic, Series, or Event-Based)
- Brand sponsorship of topic hubs, expert AMAs, or fact-checking series with guardrails to prevent editorial interference.
- Sponsors may fund public-interest fact-checking efforts without control over outcomes.

EARS Requirements — Sponsorships
- THE civicDebateBoard SHALL disclose sponsor identity on all sponsored surfaces associated with the sponsor.
- WHERE a content area is sponsored, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL prevent sponsor accounts from editing or removing user content or fact-check annotations.
- IF a sponsor attempts to influence moderation or fact-check outcomes, THEN THE civicDebateBoard SHALL document the attempt and escalate to policy governance for review.
- WHEN a sponsored AMA is scheduled, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL present sponsorship disclosure on the announcement and session surfaces throughout the campaign.
- WHERE a sponsor has a direct stake in a topic (e.g., active lobbying), THE civicDebateBoard SHALL display a conflict-of-interest label on sponsored surfaces for that topic.

### 2.3 Subscriptions (Member-Supported)
- Optional subscriptions for power users and institutions: reduced ads, advanced topic insights, and support for fact-checking capacity.
- No paywalling of core civic participation (reading, posting, voting) to preserve accessibility.

EARS Requirements — Subscriptions
- THE civicDebateBoard SHALL keep core participation features (reading, posting, voting, reporting) accessible without payment.
- WHERE subscriptions are active, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL present a clear list of benefits before purchase and on the account page thereafter.
- IF payment fails or a subscription lapses, THEN THE civicDebateBoard SHALL revert benefits within 24 hours and retain access to core participation features.
- WHEN a user cancels a subscription, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL stop future billing immediately and retain benefits until the end of the current paid period.
- WHERE institutional subscriptions are active, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL allow assignment and revocation of seats without affecting user data ownership or posting history.
- WHERE subscription benefits include reduced ad load, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL cap ad frequency at 0–1 per day per user under the plan.

### 2.4 Grants and Public-Interest Funding
- Eligibility for grants from foundations and civic institutions to support fact-checking, moderation research, or community education.

EARS Requirements — Grants
- WHEN grant funding is received for a public-interest initiative, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL separate editorial decision-making from grant reporting structures.
- WHERE a grant imposes transparency obligations, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL publish required acknowledgments on relevant program pages.

### 2.5 General Monetization Guardrails
- No sale or licensing of personal data; revenue must not depend on data brokerage.
- Monetization experiments must pass policy, privacy, and ethics review before launch.
- No pay-for-reach or pay-to-amplify mechanics in civic discourse.

EARS Requirements — Monetization Guardrails
- THE civicDebateBoard SHALL refrain from selling or licensing personal data to third parties for unrelated purposes.
- WHEN launching a monetization experiment, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL require prior governance approval with documented objectives, metrics, and guardrails.
- IF revenue objectives conflict with safety or integrity metrics, THEN THE civicDebateBoard SHALL prioritize safety and integrity and pause the conflicting initiative.
- WHERE revenue content intersects with political topics, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL apply election-period restrictions and conflict-of-interest disclosures.

## 3) User Acquisition and Growth Strategy

Growth emphasizes trust, transparency, and utility over vanity metrics.

Tactics
- Partnerships with civic organizations, universities, and local newsrooms to onboard verifiedMember contributors and host educational threads.
- Invitation flows and topic follows that return participants to relevant debates without spam or dark patterns.
- Recognition for high-quality contributions over quantity (e.g., helpfulness signals, accepted corrections).

EARS Requirements — Growth
- THE civicDebateBoard SHALL prohibit dark patterns (confusing consent, disguised ads, forced continuity) in acquisition or retention flows.
- WHEN a user invites a contact, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL send a single, clearly labeled invitation and SHALL not re-message the contact without explicit consent.
- WHERE growth notifications are enabled, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL limit notification sends to a maximum of 2 per user per day and SHALL include a one-click opt-out per category.
- IF a partner’s onboarding content violates safety policies, THEN THE civicDebateBoard SHALL remove the content and notify the partner with policy references.
- WHEN a verifiedMember application is approved per policy criteria, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL elevate the account and adjust rate limits within 1 hour.
- WHERE referral programs operate, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL cap referral benefits to prevent spam incentives and SHALL revoke benefits for abuse.

Funnel Metrics (targets; monitor monthly)
- Visitor-to-registration conversion: ≥ 15% (Amber: 10–14%; Red: < 10%).
- Registration-to-activation (first post or comment within 7 days): ≥ 60% (Amber: 45–59%; Red: < 45%).
- Activation-to-30d retention: ≥ 20% (Amber: 15–19%; Red: < 15%).

## 4) Analytics KPIs and Reporting Cadence

KPI definitions measure growth, engagement, quality, safety, and revenue while honoring privacy and consent. Metrics are aggregated with data minimization; sensitive data is excluded or aggregated as required.

EARS Requirements — Analytics and Reporting
- THE civicDebateBoard SHALL maintain a weekly operational report covering growth, engagement, quality, safety, and monetization KPIs with owner accountability.
- WHEN a KPI crosses an alert threshold, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL create an incident entry in the business review log within 24 hours and assign a responsible owner.
- WHERE consent is required for analytics, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL exclude non-consenting users from analytics cohorts and annotate reports accordingly.
- IF a metric requires sensitive data to compute, THEN THE civicDebateBoard SHALL use a privacy-preserving aggregate or omit the metric and document the omission.
- WHERE a KPI definition changes, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL version the definition and annotate trend breaks in the next report.

KPI Catalog and Targets (formulas and targets)

|-----|---------------------|---------------------------|----------------|------------------------------|---------------------|-------|---------|

| 30-Day Retention | New users active 30 days after registration | Returners day 30 / new registrations | ≥ 20% | Amber: 15–19%; Red: < 15% | Role, source | Product Analytics | Monthly |

| Report Review SLA (Standard) | Hours to decision for standard reports | Hours elapsed from report creation | ≤ 24 h | Amber: 25–48; Red: > 48 | Category, team | Safety Lead | Daily |
| False Positive Rate (Moderation) | Sanctions overturned on appeal | Overturned / total sanctions | ≤ 5% | Amber: 5.1–8%; Red: > 8% | Category, team | Safety QA | Monthly |
| Re-offense Rate | Sanctioned users who re-offend within 60 days | Re-offenders / sanctioned users | ≤ 10% | Amber: 10.1–15%; Red: > 15% | Category, sanction | Safety QA | Monthly |
| Subscription Conversion | Eligible users starting paid plan within 30 days | New subscribers / eligible users | ≥ 2.5% | Amber: 1.5–2.4%; Red: < 1.5% | Role, region | Monetization Lead | Monthly |
| ARPPU | Average revenue per paying user per month | Revenue from paid users / count of paid users | ≥ $8.00 | Amber: $6.00–7.99; Red: < $6.00 | Plan type, region | Finance | Monthly |
| Ad Fill Rate | Served ad impressions / eligible ad opportunities | Impressions served / eligible opportunities | ≥ 85% | Amber: 70–84%; Red: < 70% | Context, region | Monetization Lead | Weekly |
| Ad Frequency (per user/day) | Average ads per eligible user per day | Ads / eligible user-days | ≤ 2.0 | Amber: 2.1–3.0; Red: > 3.0 | Role, region | Monetization Lead | Weekly |
| Opt-out Rate (Personalized Ads) | Users opting out of personalized ads | Opt-outs / active users | ≤ 10% | Amber: 10.1–15%; Red: > 15% | Region | Privacy Lead | Monthly |
| Consent Coverage | Active users with recorded analytics consent state | Users with consent state / active users | 100% | Amber: 98–99.9%; Red: < 98% | Region | Privacy Lead | Monthly |

Reporting Cadence
- Weekly Ops Review: Growth, engagement, quality, safety, revenue highlights; action items with owners and due dates.
- Monthly Business Review: Trend analysis, budget vs. actuals, experiment outcomes, compliance review notes.
- Quarterly Strategy Review: Deep-dive on mission metrics, risks, policy landscape, and roadmap adjustments.

KPI Governance
- THE civicDebateBoard SHALL maintain a metric registry with owner, purpose, definition, lawful basis/consent status, retention period, and version history.
- WHEN a KPI definition changes, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL mark a trend break and attach the new definition version to subsequent reports.
- WHERE a metric is deprecated, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL archive its definition and rationale in the registry.

## 5) Content Quality and Community Health Metrics

Quality and health take precedence over volume. Metrics emphasize constructive engagement and corrective transparency.

EARS Requirements — Quality and Health
- THE civicDebateBoard SHALL compute quality metrics using privacy-preserving aggregates and SHALL avoid tracking users across unrelated contexts.
- WHEN a topic’s Net Helpfulness Score remains below 0 for seven consecutive days, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL trigger a community health review with proposed remediation actions.
- WHERE factChecker coverage falls below the alert threshold, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL prioritize recruitment or scheduling for fact-checking resources in the affected topics.
- IF a content area exhibits repeated misinformation patterns, THEN THE civicDebateBoard SHALL introduce friction measures (pre-post reminders, source citation prompts) consistent with policy.
- WHEN verifiedMember posts include expert tags, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL present expert context labels to readers.

Additional Health Metrics and Definitions
- Civility Incident Rate: ≤ 1.5% of posts flagged for civility violations per week. Definition: number of posts flagged for civility divided by total posts that week.
- Repeat Correction Visibility: ≥ 95% of accepted corrections remain visible on original content indefinitely. Definition: corrected items with visible corrections / total corrected items.
- Topic Diversity Index: ≥ 0.65 across top 20 topics by volume each quarter. Definition: normalized Shannon diversity index on topic distribution.
- Constructive Participation Ratio: ≥ 85% of comments pass civility and relevance checks in monitored threads (Amber: 75–84%; Red: < 75%).

## 6) Moderation and Safety Metrics

Safety protects discourse quality and user well-being.

EARS Requirements — Moderation and Safety
- THE civicDebateBoard SHALL prioritize critical severity reports to the front of the queue and SHALL meet the Time to First Moderator View target.
- WHEN a sanction is issued, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL present the policy citation and evidence links to the user at enforcement time.
- WHERE sanctions include temporary restrictions, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL automatically restore privileges upon expiry without further user action.
- IF an appeal is submitted within the allowed window, THEN THE civicDebateBoard SHALL review and decide within 72 hours and SHALL notify the appellant of the outcome and rationale.
- WHEN a moderator action is overturned, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL update the audit trail and recalculate related metrics within 24 hours.

Safety SLA Targets
- Critical Harms (doxxing, threats): First view ≤ 30 minutes; decision ≤ 2 hours.
- Standard Reports: Decision ≤ 24 hours.
- Appeals: Decision ≤ 72 hours; overturn rate ≤ 5%.
- Harm Escalation Rate: ≤ 2% of unresolved P1 items escalate to P0 within 12 hours.

## 7) Governance for Data Use and Ethics

Governance ensures analytics and monetization respect privacy, comply with policy, and preserve civic integrity. Applies to product, monetization, policy, and research uses of data.

Principles
- Data minimization and purpose limitation for analytics and monetization.
- Transparency in user disclosures for ads, sponsorships, and data use.
- No sale of personal data; no political microtargeting based on sensitive attributes.

EARS Requirements — Governance
- THE civicDebateBoard SHALL maintain a register of analytics metrics with documented purpose, lawful basis or consent requirement, and retention period.
- WHEN a new metric or experiment requires additional data collection, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL conduct a privacy impact assessment and obtain governance approval before launch.
- WHERE user consent is withdrawn, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL exclude the user’s data from future analytics and SHALL remove the user from longitudinal cohorts within 7 days where legally feasible.
- IF an ethics or compliance breach is suspected, THEN THE civicDebateBoard SHALL initiate an incident review within 24 hours and SHALL notify relevant stakeholders per compliance requirements.
- WHILE a government election moratorium period is active, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL disable political audience refinements and SHALL restrict political ad activations.
- WHERE a KPI or experiment materially affects user rights or safety SLAs, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL escalate to policy governance for pre-approval.

Experimentation Policy
- Pre-registration: hypothesis, metrics (including safety guardrails), eligibility, duration, and stop criteria recorded in the experiment registry.
- Exposure limits: per-user cap of concurrent experiments (e.g., maximum 3) and maximum duration (e.g., 6 weeks) to reduce fatigue and risk.
- Safety guardrails: experiments must not degrade safety metrics beyond predefined bounds (e.g., no more than +10% P1 incidents vs. control).

EARS Requirements — Experimentation
- THE civicDebateBoard SHALL require experiment pre-registration including objectives, primary/secondary metrics, and safety guardrails.
- WHEN an experiment begins, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL create a holdback/control cohort and SHALL enforce exposure caps per user.
- IF safety guardrails breach (e.g., P1 incidents +10% vs. control), THEN THE civicDebateBoard SHALL pause the experiment within 24 hours and initiate a review.
- WHERE experiments affect monetization exposure (ads, sponsorships), THE civicDebateBoard SHALL verify compliance with advertising and sponsorship guardrails before launch.
- WHEN an experiment concludes, THE civicDebateBoard SHALL publish a summary with metric outcomes and decisions in the experiment registry.

Access Governance and Data Ethics
- Role-based data access for analytics respecting least-privilege; aggregated outputs for general stakeholders.
- Retention for analytics datasets aligned to the metric registry; avoid indefinite retention without purpose.
